29.04.2011. 0,355l Bottle. ICA Maxi Haugesund. Pale yellow hazy beer with white head. Aroma is rather thin wheaty with moderate bitterness. A little thin body. There are some aroma hops, but finish is short and aftertaste does not taste good.
Bottle. From notes. Slightly hazy golden. Yeast, wheat, spices, citrus. Ligh-bodied.

It poured a golden yellow with a decent white head. The aroma was notes of fruit, citrus and light wheat. The flavor was sweet with notes of fruits and citrus. It was very fruity with low hints of wheat.  An ok wheat ale.
Really not that good at all. Very light almost watery palate. Not much aroma besides some light spices and cloves. Taste is much the same. Not much going on

Tap: Poured a light bright yellow color ale with a small foamy head with limited retention. Aroma consists of wheat malt with semi-sweet notes. Taste is also dominated by wheat malt with light sugary notes. Body is about average with good carbonation. Not much more then a middle of the road wheat ale.

Bottle. Pours a very light, pale straw, with a decent head. Aroma of sweet orange and light caramel, with a slight touch of spice. Initial acidic flavour of citrus and fruit followed by a malty sweetness of toffee, followed by a sweet finish. A good, decent beer, but without any remarkable features.
12oz bottle, thin head, hazy almost white appearance. just a light aroma of hops and spice. taste is a little bland and watery. light spice finish

Bottle.  Light yellow hazy color, small white head. Thin aroma of malt and yeast. Sweet taste with some wheat and yeast, a bit refreshing, but not as much taste as expected from a wheat. The positive is that the beer is now availible in many grocery stores in Oslo, who mostly just have boring canned pale lagers. Compared to them I find this a good alternative when picking up a couple of beers in the hot weather.

Pours golden wheat color (go figure) with a small white head.  Heavy hay/grass aroma (go figure).  Medium sour taste with the very faintest bitter on the back end.  Very light beer.  Almost nothing to it really.  Not a great wheat beer.  It fits the bill for being light and refreshing, but it’s too light and the refreshing nature is more from just having a cold, slightly carbonated beverage.
Quick-review: Unclear, light yellow with a shade of green. Plain smell, alitlle malt, but not much. Taste of malt, alittle fruity. Boring.

12oz bottle in Chicago. Saw this all over the place, lots of adverts. ’not like any other goose island’.. i’d say so, quite boring and pretty flavorless. I guess it is a good starting point for new beer fans. Slightly sweet grain, summer fruits. Probably great when it’s hot out but not anything to seek out.

Bottle. Yellow hazy, thick foamy white head. Smell is not as expected. Some malty smells and maybe some hints of yeasts. Taste is also malty and sweet, but quite light at the same time. Miss some more refreshing tastes and aromaes here. Where’s the citrus and banana? Not bitter finish eighter. Very boring beer

Bottle, 12oz. An unclear, yellow beer with a small, white head. Citrus and wheat in the weak aroma. The flavor is citrusy and wheaty, lacking on bitterness and punch. Flat, medium body, short and uninteresting finish. A beer that drinks easily but also bores the hell out of me. Rating: 5-3-5-2-10-2.5. 20110330

Bottle, 12oz. An unclear, yellow beer with a small, dense, white head. Mostly citrusy on the nose, with a touch of spices in the back. Wheat too. The flavor is on the citrusy side, on a backdrop of pale malts. Slightly spiced and acidic, rather thin on the palate and with too low levels of carbonation. Citrusy finish, blending oranges and lemon in a smooth, lemonade like way. Well, it’s quite quenching, but it’s certainly nothing impressive going on. Well, I think I’ll have a few more during the spring and summer, it’s certainly better than the lagers we’re used to in Norway, and the price isn’t too high either. 110413
fra flaske, dufter dejligt af spicy frugter, flot gylden en anelse grumset..med flot hvidt skum...smager dejligt spicy med frugter ....let fylde med en eftersmag af hvede....ialt en ok wheat ale
Bottle. Pours cloudy yellow with a medium white head. The aroma is cereal, malt, wheat and citrus. The flavour is quite citrussy with notes of hops and wheat.

From bottle. Appears cloudy, as advertised. Hops have a floral, citrusy taste that makes this drink refreshing, but it finishes very short. Much less of a bite than I prefer, very short flavor, but for some that may be a good thing. Kind of sour taste.

Bottle from Voldby Købmandsgaard
very clear yellow,  smooth large white head with a yellow tone.
fresh flowery hoppy aroma, slightly dusty, notes of peaches quite delicate and pretty pleasing flowery aroma.
flavor is flowery, very slightly hoppy bitter, slightrly fruity and wheaty. Very mild and probably also a bit boring wheat beer - i prefer the german and belgian versions of wheat beer to this. However it is quite refreshing and very easy to drink, almost like a lemon soda water, or a radler. second pour was not entirely clear, but still it’s one of the most clear berws i ever saw , that claims to be unfiltered.

0.33l bottle @ Biskopen. Pours a light semi hazy yellow - almost lemonade-like body with a thin quickly fading white head. Aromas are really low, but there are hints of yeast, wheat and something sour that I can’t figure out what is (could it be sour cardboard perhaps?). The body is as light and watery as is looks and the carbonation is lively as hell. Tastes blend and watery. Notes of banana, yeast and perhaps some clove, but the (too) lively carbonation and watery body made this a boring experience.
There aren’t too many Wheat Ales I don’t like, but this one is a refreshing beer that is just an easy going drink.

Goose Island 312 Urban Wheat Ale is a cloudy, pale straw colored beer with a thin white head that fades to film and leaves decent lacing on the glass.  There’s not much aroma, just a faint metallic whiff and a note of lemon.  It has a very Lively light body with a crisp, dry finish.  There’s not much flavor; a little wheat with a hint of grassy bitterness.  It has good balance.  This is like doing it in a canoe, so it goes down quite easily.  It has no faults.
Bottle 355ml at Beer2000. Hazy pale yellow with small white head. Faint aroma of wheat, bread. Taste is light sweet, light bitter. Light to medium body, thin, soft carbonation. Disappointed.

Bottle 355ml @ Beer2000

Pours clear pale yellow with a white head. Aroma has notes of malt. wheat, caramel and fruity hops. Taste is light sweet and light bitter. Body is light, texture is thin, carbonation is soft.
Bottle.Pours cloudy pale yellow with a white head.Aroma of honey, wheat, grains, bread and yeast.Flavor is sweet and wheaty with some flour and bitterness.Medium to thin body.

Wow somehow I hadn’t rated this yet....and perfect timing with the new AB buyout! 12 oz bottle. Pours a light slightly hazy yellow orange with a small creamy white head. Aroma is sweet and lightly citric, a bit bready with a touch of honey sweetness. Flavor starts light and sweet with some bits of orange zest, some wheat and a soft fruit note. Finishes a bit on the grainy bread side. Medium body and a sharp carbonation. Eh, it’s a pretty standard middle of the road American wheat

On tap at BW3 into a 16oz plastic cup, way to keep it classy...A light hazy gold with a decent white head, good retention...The aroma is light wheat, slightly skunky. The taste is boring as heck, skunky bite to it, light sweet wheat. Not sure why people think this is a good, a small step above a macro.

Pours a light pale clear yellow color with a full white head.  Smells of lemon, grass, and some light yeast.  Initially, a bit of the hops come through giving way to some decent grainy flavors.  The finish is really short.  Overall, it’s a very simplistic beer.

355 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. ABV is 4.4%. Pale golden colour, hazy when the yeast is poured in, moderate white head. Spicy aroma, notes of cloves and coriander, hints of ripe bananas. Plenty of carbonation in the mouth.. Refreshing flavour, spicy notes again, a touch of banana, but the beer is quite dry.

Bottle @ Biskopen, Bergen. Hazy light yellow body, small diminishing white head. Nose is wheat, citrus, clove and hints of banana and baker’s yeast. Taste is citrusy tones with grass and some herbal hints. I know there’s no coriander in this beer but it reminds me so much of a Belgian wit that I can’t help catching it in the aftertaste nevertheless...the mind and senses work together in funny ways. Refreshing and OK, but nothing really special.

Great head. The nose as my friend has just pointed out, smells of cat’s pee or even worse. The taste is light with gentle notes of hops and malts. Drinkable but not memorable. Easily the worst Goose Island beer I’ve ever had - well behind their usual high standard.

A: The beer pours a slightly hazed bright yellow color with a short lived white head.

S: Fairly light on the nose but some definite citrus notes of lemon peel and orange.  A decent enough floral hop character is present as well.  Sweet bread and wheat in terms of the malt content.

T: Much more yeasty than I had expected.  Wheat bread is there, but the flavor is quite light as well.  Lemon zest and a mild to moderate tartness.  Not as much hop flavor as I had anticipated, given the nose.

M: Light in body with a moderate level of carbonation.

O: As far as the Pale Wheat style of beer goes, this isn’t bad, but it’s still not something I’d care to drink again.

Pours very clear with only a slight tinge of yellow with a small White with visible high carbonation. Not much on the nose, smells a bit lager like with a grain of wheat. Very refreshing would like to see in my local curry house but, doesnâ€™t really have any impressive tasting notes. In the palette, very inoffensive, note leaving of an impression, hard to believe this is from an American craft brewery. Very watery. Poor show from a useilly solid brewery

Sign of the Whale, DC tap ($6): Usually I don’t get wheat beers, but this was the only beer in the place that I have never tried and was amongst the better beers in the dive bar. In any case, it pours a hazy yellow and has a thoroughly citrus taste. It is very light bodied and it seems like you could drink 15 of these without noticing. Anyway, I find it astounding that most people here are saying that this isn’t true to the style or that you could barely tell that this is a wheat ale. I think this is ridiculous. This is about as clearly an American wheat as any that I’ve had. The fruitiness, the haziness, and the light body are all there.
By far the worst wateriest beer I’ve had. Well maybe boddingtons but still, this is water.

Pint at Maggie’s (Watertown). 20FE11.



App.:  Hazy golden with a thin white head.
  
Aroma:  Clean minerals, citrus, some toasted wheat and grain, a little honey, a bit of earthy coriander.
  
Palate: Medium body, gentle effervescence. 
  
Flav.:  Some banana esters, yeast, toasted wheat, a bit of citrus, grains/cereals, some coriander (I think...).



Hard to guess the style, OK though.
POurs yellow with a light head.  Light notes of citurs on the nose with a light ale like quality that shows a bit of whaet character.  Nice easy finish.

Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is wheaty, fruity and yeasty. Flavor is rather sweet and light bitter. Sweet finish. A bit watery and lacks body. There is something artificial about the fruity sweetness. 010311

light gold, very hazy
nose is citrus hops and a little yeast
Med/thin and fizzy
some citrus hops, can’t find any wheat beer flavour. it’s not really a wheat beer other than the unfiltered bit. 
meh.
extremely inoffensive boring wheat beer. Almost macrobrew. Shame on you goose island.
Bottle from the Criterion, Leicester. Fairly undetectable wheat on an APA background. Pleasant enough, but not a wheat beer in the sense that I understand it.

Poured on tap at goose island brewery in wrigleyville.  Smell is citrus and sweet.  Taste is semi wheat, citrus, lemon and little hops.  Tastes like my kolsch I brewed in December.  This beer was filtered which does not contribute true to the style of wheat beer.  Very clear like a pilsner.  Would have again, but this beer is in a class of its own..
Bottle.   Pours hazy yellow with thin white head.  Citrus flavor with lemons and oranges.  Decent.

Thanks to Justin for the 12 sampler pack. Pours a light yellow, hazy with a thick white head. Wheat, touch of citrus and cardboard in the aroma. Smooth wheat in the taste, touch of citrus in the taste. Decent.
Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a hazy light yellow with a thin white head and no lacing, aroma is sweet with some citrus and the flavor is fairly boring with notes of lemon and wheat, meh.
Always a favorite when I am in Chicago, just enjoyed a few in Missouri as I waited out the snow storm of 2011. I wish i could get it in Miami
Rather watery, don’t know why it tastes like a reminiscent of a rather weak interpretation of a English Ale.

Can’t believe I have never rated this before. For some reason, this seems to be the go-to microbrew in the Chicago area, but I’ve never really bought into the hype as this brewery has so many better offerings. Thin, golden body with aromas of wheat and citrusy malt. Light mouthfeel with lemon citrus, wheat and hop notes that fade into a metallic finish. Not my favorite.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy bright yellow and gold, with a small white head.  Aromas of funky malt and mushroom....hmm, weird.  The flavor is very similar, with funky mushrooms and some strange malt notes.  This almost certainly has to be a skunked, and/or old bottle; if not, then dear God, what a shame.

It looks nice out of the bottle with a cloudy yellow color and a thin head, it has a citrus flavor that fades rather quickly into a clean finish and somewhat watery finish.  I like many other Goose Island brews, but this one was a little disappointing.
This is an okay IPA, I wasn’t terribly impressed with it. Some floral aromas, but I’d like a lot more hoppiness in an IPA.

(Bottle) Golden yellow colour, slightly hazy, with frothy white head. Fruity, wheaty nose with white bread, wheat flour dough, honey, apricots, citrus and grass. Fruity, malty taste with notes of apricots, white bread, honey and citric hints of lemon and orange. Light body, fairly dry, with low bitterness. Rather harmless, but tasty and refreshing. Quite enjoyable.

poured from single 12oz bottle - Looks unpleasing as any domestic light beer.  Some pleasant aromas come off this thing.  Wheat is noticeable on the nose and tongue.  Pleasant citrus and light creaminess.  I didn’t think I would be defending this one from a less-than-great 2.8 avg., but it’s honestly very refreshing.
Hazy golden yellow with a thin white head. Faint citrus aroma. Nice smooth palate, I like the mouthfeel. Blend of wheat and other cereal grain malt flavors on the palate. Refreshing.

Had this at Bubba Gump’s at the Navy Pier, poured into a pint glass.

2.5 A: Nearly clear golden color. This beer should be cloudy and I looked at other reviews to verify that it is not filtered. (I had a FILTERED APWA before and it sucked, so now I’m always weary when an APWA is clear.) Also, there was no head to speak of since the beer was poured right up to the top of the weizen glass. Pretty much an awful, uneducated pour. I wish I didn’t have to do this, but I have to review it like I see it. Hopefully I’ll be able to try it again before leaving Chicago so I can give it respectable marks. Sorry Goose Island.

3.5 S: Aroma was pretty bland, but not unpleasant. Most APWAs aren’t exciting (in the nose) unless it gets a good hopping. Anyway, mainly neutral wheat aroma.

3.5 T: A respectable brew even with the yeast MIA. Solid wheat flavor with a very mild spiciness to it. Also a very mild citrus hop flavor.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good carbonation. No problems.

4.0 D: Very smooth the whole way through. I find most APWAs extremely drinkable and this is no different. Tasty enough to make another a good idea.

Serving type: on-tap

Reviewed on: 06-27-2009 04:54:06

Light and wheaty aroma.  Golden in color.  Didn’t take good notes on this one, will have to give it another try sometime.

Notes: GABF ’09

Just like the commercial description says.  Very light and refreshing.  Light fruity aroma, cloudy golden,pour  fluffy head.  Malty toward bready, as expected.  Perhaps the most agreeable wheat beer I have had to date.
Bottle. Golden with a small head and slightly hazy. Gentle trace of wheat with some bitterness added. Pleasant if uninspiring.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours hazy orange with a small white head. Aroma is mild fruity. Light peachy to mango citrusy hops flavoured. Smooth mouthfeel. Crisp peachy, subdued sweetness and light bitterness. Mellow and smooth finish.

Bottle and draft.  Not a bad beer, especially for a lazy summer afternoon or evening.  Its wheat character is light and a bit watery, and almost juicy.  Its pleasant, but very tamed.  Easy going summer session brew though.
Very plain and normal wheat beer, only tolerable with a slice of lemon or an orange. Blah.
bottle, from pawola22, cloudy golden color with thin creamy foam, aromas of sweet peach and pineapples, flavors of hoppy tropical fruits, honeysuckle,.nice finish

12 ounce bottle from thetomG in Secret Santa Winter 10. Thanks! Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a large creamy white head. Good head retention and sticky lacing. Aroma of bread, citrus, stone fruits and a bitter finish. The taste is bitter citrus notes, some tropical notes as well, wheat, bread, an almost crackery note. Nutty finish. Thin-medium bodied. Solidly made and would probably be very nice to session during the summer.
Clear yellow with a fluffy white head.  Sweet bread aroma and taste with good strong citrus throughout and a wheat bread finish.

On tap.

A - Hazed, pale gold color with an average sized, whispy, creamy, frothy, tight, pearl white head. Decent retention with a thin layer of lace.

S - Nice tart lemony aroma with some grassy and banana hints as well. Good amount of malted wheat aroma gives it a base. Pretty well spiced but nothing too strong. Pretty typical for the style.

T - Pretty nice, refreshing taste. Wheat and grainy base are nice and provide a lot of the flavor. A good level of lemon rind, grass/lemongrass, spice and just a hint of banana. Pretty zesty/tart for the style, but balanced out by the wheat flavor.

M - Light body with very nice carbonation. Quite creamy and goes down very smooth.

D - Very easy to drink, smooth, refreshing beer. Has enough zest and spice to keep it interesting and have me coming back for more.

Notes: Very nice pale wheat beer that is quite refreshing. Good summertime, thirst quencher. Also has a good amount of spice, zest, and hints of hops to kick up the wheat a bit.
12 oz bottle.  Pours lightly hazed golden with a white head.  Aroma is wheaty with a bit of cloves.  Flavor is light wheat, lemony, and some citrus hops.  It’s alright, but unexciting.
Bottle from Voldby. Nice head with good duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are sweet wheat malt, and hops. Mild and easy drinkable.

G: Poured into a weizen glass.

A: Pours a pale yellow with a hint a lemony brightness. Slightly cloudy with a good amount of carbonation bubbles. Two-finger white head.

S: Sweet with some citrus spice. 

T: Sweet with pale malt and a definite citrus glaze. An ever-so-slight amount of bitterness. 

M: A little bit heavy on the carbonation. Also, a tiny bit too much citrus on the swallow.

D: Clean, light, refreshing. Good summer beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-24-2009

22 oz. bottle from Woodman’s Market in Madison, WI.  Hazy pale yellow pour with a thick, creamy white head.  Aroma of light citrus and sweet candi-like malts.  Light lemon and orange flavors complement the predominant wheat ale flavor well.  This was somewhere between a witbier and a hefeweizen (unlike some wheat ales that are not indistinguishable in flavor from witbiers or hefeweizens).  This was good overall.
Bottle @ Home. Light golden with a small white head. Wheat, lemon and light spices in the nose. Taste is more less like nose, light lemon,spices and wheat. Thin body, lively carbonation.

Bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow color with a small longlasting white head. Has a fruity wheat malty aroma with some hints of citrus. Sweetish wheat malty flavor with some hints of citrus and some grainy hints. Has a sweetish wheat malty grainy finish.

Ölen är ljus, och det ska den ju vara, men jag tycker nog att denna ser lite blaskig ut och lite för genomskinlig. Den klassiska lite grumligheten jag är van vid från andra veteöl, är helt borta här. På kortet ser ölen ut till att ha en hyfsat skumtopp, men den försvann några sekunder efter.

Doften: Den doftar absolut ingen ting. Ingen vete, ingen frukt… ingen ting!
Smaken: Jag måste verkligen leta efter smakerna, men hittar inte mycket. Kanske en liten aning hö, men då är jag mycket snäll. Fantastisk dålig öl.
Wheat, lemon rind aroma. Flavor is wheat, citrus, and fresh grains. Fairly typical american wheat... thirst quenching I guess.

Tap at Mad Hatter. Pours a translucent, glowing straw color almost like a witbier with a medium, bright white head leaving pretty good lace. Aroma is grainy, slight lemon, fresh bread. Taste is cream of wheat, slight sweet cherries, lots of yeasty/doughy presence, no balancing bitterness or spice.
Bottle. Hazy yellow with a fluffy white head. Light yeast and lemon aroma. A very light yeasty flavor, light lemon. Thin bodied with some carbonation. Overall very watered down with little flavor.
Nothing special, straw colored and tastes like a typical wheat.  Nothing earth shattering.

Bottle poured a hazy yellow with a lingering ring of white foam. Aromas of wheat, lemon and light yeast. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of wheat, light yeast and light lemon with a crisp lingering wheat finish.

On tap at Hub 51 in Chicago. Cloudy pale yellow, modest white head. Zesty spicy aroma with lemony accents. Interesting palate in that it is a little toastier than I would expect from a wheat, lightly spicy, lemony accents. Normally wheat ales bore the shit out of me, but this wasn’t bad. Like a pale ale/wheat ale hybrid.
Chicago’s finest, Goose Island. I prefer the Stout, but 312 is probably their most famous.

I live in Chicago and have probably had this beer hundreds of times in all forms - so I’m finally getting around to rating it. The best I’ve ever had it was a very fresh keg from the liquor store across the street from Goose Island poured from a Handpump. In that form the beer is rich and wheatey with smooth grain notes and a hint of bitterness. However, when served from a stale keg or drunk straight from the bottle the carbonation ruins and delicate wheat flavor and the hops take over making 312 instead taste like a skunked up watered down pale ale. Enjoy this beer, but enjoy it fresh.
Not quite for me.  I’m not much of a wheat fan anyway.  Was OK, though not a lot going on with it.  Would be a good session beer I suppose, but the wheat undertones turn me off.
On tap.  Golden color. Nice head.  Very refreshing.  One of the better rip session beers I have had in a while.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz bottle into a Weizen glass. The label has a "Bottled On" date but no ABV%

Appearance: It has a very light hazy straw yellow color with some fine yeast sediment in suspension. There is a little visible carbonation as well that helps support it nice foamy white head. The head hangs on well and makes a few cool lace rings near the top of the glass.

Smell: The aroma is light and has a simple clean bready/yeast character. 

Taste/Palate: There is a light clean bready/biscuit like malt base with a very light hop bitterness. The finish is snappy and the light body and texture are refreshing.

Notes: There not much to say. It hits its mark as a basic Pale Wheat Ale.

12oz bottle bottled less than two weeks ago.   Unfiltered but not bottle conditioned and no sediment... so a light-to-medium hazy yellow color with a lasting medium-sized white head.   The aroma is soft and doughy wheat malt with a very faint hop spice and touch or rose and sweetened cranberry.   Lightly fruity and floral in the mouth with low bitterness, light wheaty sweetness, and a dry, grainy finish.   Higher carbonation and a light body.   Considerable better after it warmed up for twenty minutes or so.   Very bland and hard in the mouth right out of the fridge, despite it being hot and muggy out.   I definitely got a little into this after awhile, but it’s not quite interesting enough for me to put up in the retry list.

This pours a golden-yellow color with a thick fluffy white head that dies down to a thin layer.  It definitely smells wheaty.  Whiffs of lemon, flowers, and all around spring air in there.  This beer is refreshing enough I suppose but it’s really limited.  Some citrusy flavors with wheat and herbs but I’m having trouble coming up with much to say.  Perhaps because there just isn’t much there.  Bland and watery but not undrinkable.  With lower expectations this should be fine for the summer weather.

On draft @ The Union Pub in DC.  Hazy golden pour, thick one finger white head, very sticky.  Aroma was of wheat, grassyness, and some lemony citrus.  Lots of citrus flavors up front, super crisp, refreshing with a super dry finish.  A very decent wheat.  I am becoming a big fan of Goose Island.

Thin flavor, feels like light beer.
Hops: citrus
Yeast/Bacteria: sweat
Color: pale
Liquid: hazy
Head: minimal
Initial: light sweetness, light sourness
Finish: medium sourness
Finish Duration: short
Body: light
Texture: thin
Carbonation: soft
Finish: abrupt

Bottle- served in a weizen as instructed. Misting straw, fine uneven collar. Bright, zesty, lemon meringue and pineapple jelly aroma like an English GA. Lemon curd on wholemeal toast with dabs of sherbet and honey; squeeze of lime, tingling condition. Lemon puff biscuit finish with soapy bitterness and perfumed hop. Refreshing.

On tap in Chicago O’Hare. Cloudy gold with a thin white head. Yeast dominates the aroma. Taste follows the aroma with a hint of citrus destroyed by yeast and wheat. Slightly bitter. No significant aftertaste.
Sampled at Giordino’s in downtown Chicago. Pours really pale yellow. Has a bit of head on it. Not your best quality wheat brew but its well made.

Pours a light opaque color typical of a wheat ale. Aroma is citrusy and hoppy but a little more doughy/stale than expected. Flavor was very mild and bitter with some sweet/spicyness. Nothing really too special. Palate is simple, taste like the aroma. This is good for a commercial wheat.
Pours a hazy straw color. Moderate white head with good retention and lacing. Aroma is wheat and tart citrus. Similar flavor. Minimal aftertaste. Very refreshing lawnmower beer.
Very mild, easy to drink. Nothing off flavor wise, just a very mellow beer. Like a blue moon light I guess.
A great wheat beer, cloudy gold in color like a good wheat should, pair well with any citrus if desire, and a presidential favorite. Top ten in best wheat beer in my opinon
Yellowish with a small white head. The aroma is weak with light fruit hints and a bit of malt. Flavour is mild like the aroma. Watery palate.

From Voldby, DK.
Bottled, 180810.
Yellow with white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus and spices. Flavor with some fruit notes.

I enjoyed this beer a great deal. I ordered a 32 ounce cup of this on tap at an Avett Brothers concert and had a good deal of it gone before I could even get back to where I was standing for the show. Appearance is a hazy yellow. Taste was like a yeasty bread and the palate was banana nut bread. Great beer that I would love to try when I’m sober.

On tap at Winking Lizard. Yellow pour with a surprisingly thin head. Weak aroma of wheat and citrus. Flavor doesn’t take the aromas much further. Watery mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Nothing worth seeking out.

Bottled.  A hazy straw coloured beer with a white head.  A wheaty yeasty aroma with a bit of fizzy fruit and a bit of orange.  Middle of the road fruity wheaty flavours.  Just an average beer but it’s a boring style.

I get what Goose was going for.  Something good for summer, low flavor that was easy drinking.  It has succeeded in terms of it is very popular.  And I am sure it is good at what it is trying to be. However this is not my kind of thing at all. It has just enough flavor to and just enough watery-ness to confuse the taste buds and make me fussy.  It is exactly what I don’t like about wheat ales. Serving: Bottle

The color is ok and the aroma decent but when I put this beer to my lips and drink all I can think of is cold dishwater or dirty taps.  I am a big fan of Goose Island otherwise with their other brews but this one always dissapoints.
Little let down by goose island. This as a pale yellow Hefe with some boring citrus and spice hotes. Needed a lemon wedge to make this most interesting. Guess it a decent middle of the road beer.

Sampled at SBWF09
Hazy golden. white head.
Light fruity and cereal aroma.
Thin body with some citrus.

Much like Rock Bottom, my Goose Island tasters were an impressive display of 5oz mini-nonic glasses. In my 5oz mini-nonic taster rested the hazy golden-straw depths of the 312 Urban Wheat, while atop her visage rested a fluffy white head. Her nose is lemon zest freshly squeezed over soft loaves of white and wheat bread while a whiff of coriander and white pepper drifts on by. A wheat beer, and rightfully named as such, I am glad to see she doesn’t try to claim a German heritage that is not hers to claim. Mixed in with the lemon zest is a pleasing pith and skin bitterness. Light and refreshing, without further ado I put her palate to the test. Soft lemon cream and white breads caress my tongue and mouth, gliding across with supple finesse. Lemon soothes front and middle while white and wheat breads fill her middle and finish. Speaking of her finish, it is clean with little lingering esters to speak of, just a sense of brightness and lemon skin. Coriander and white pepper play in the background, mischief makers that they are, making fast friends with the lemon zest prevalent throughout her whole palate. Clean, refreshing, and even invigorating, I am proud to say I took home a screaming canary yellow 312 Urban Wheat t-shirt to mark the occasion.




This is what American wheat beers do best, and also why they are recognized as a style separate from Belgian Wits and German Hefeweizens. If more American craft brewers would recognize this, the possibilities they would create for their own wheat beers would be endless. In the meantime, Goose Island is ahead of the game.
Light citrus aroma, some citrus and wheat in the flavor with a crisp finish. Refreshing but not overly complex.

Pours a one finger white head that vanishes, leaving no lace. Very pale, hazy yellow/green color. Light carbonation and very light bodied. Lemon nose. Flavor is more lemon than wheat some sweetness. Good session beer but needs more backbone.  $1.95 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.
Pours golden yellow with 2 finger white head. Smells of malts, slightly sour. Medium body, tastes of toasted malts and wheat; bitter.
Bottled on 5/03/10. Hazy gold pour with somewhat rocky white head. Aroma is skunk, some sweetness, wheat. Flavor is wheat, some citrus, some skunkiness. Wish this was fresher.

Bottle- Hazy golden yellow with a foamy head that fades quickly. Some light lacing. Has a light aroma of citrus and grain. light fruit & citrus with touch of bitterness. Light body that is clean & crisp- Refreshing I’m not big on wheat beers but this is a nice summer beer and could enjoy more that one.

312 Urban Wheat Ale pours a light yellow with a white head.  The aroma is a strong grapefruit with a grassy undertone.  The taste a light bitterness that is pleasantly refreshing.  The palate is also light with plenty of carbonation.  The 312 Urban Wheat Ale is very refreshing, but it does not set itself apart from the pack.
355 ml bottle. Slightly hazy pale yellow with small white head. Flavour is wheat, dry, watery and citrus.
Pale hazy yellow appearance. Sweet citrus aroma. Light flavor. Rather boring and less than impressive.

It’s hazy, light golden with a creamy, lasting, white head. The aroma has notes of fruit, citrus and light wheat. The flavour is sweet with notes of peach, citrus and other fruits. It’s very fruity with low priority on wheat, and IMO as such uninteresting.
Botella. Hazy yellow colour with a medium white head. Aroma of wheat hops and some citrus. Good mouthfeel. Fresh wheaty, fruity and citrus flavour with some bitterness. Nice.

12oz bottle pours hazy golden/straw with light diminishing head. Aroma of honey, wheat, floral. Taste of citrus, wheat, slightly spicy flavors, a little too bitter for my liking. Not great. Not a huge wheat fan though, but like this more than most.

Bottle, bought @ Kolding Vinhandel.

Very pale yellow with some haziness to it. Small, fizzy, frothy, white head. Aroma has lots of grapefruit, almost getting a fresh fruit note rather than hops. Light piney, some sweet wheat. Higish carbonation, rather watery palate. Flavour is mild, some clear sweetnesss, light grainy, the fruity hops are there, adding some flavour, but not enough bitterness, Still fairly fresh and very drinkable. I’d just rather have a Drink in the Sun.

Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Pale yellow colour. Light malty and moderate hoppy and nice citrus aroma. Grape notes. Light bitter fresh acetic (grape) flavor. Average light bitter finish. Oily palate. Nice and fresh.
Pours a very cloudy yellow color with a white head.  Aroma is of malts, wheat, skunk, coriander, and some earthiness.  Flavor is of wheat, citrus, caramel, and spices.  Leaves an earthy wheat finish.
Fruity, lamon and peaches. Roses, perfume, sweet finish. OK, a bit puzzling. Not something I would want as an everyday tipple.

bottled. pours pale golden with an average white head. smells of citrus and herb and grass. it is lightly sweet and light bodied. not much finish. reminds me of bud light wheat more than a craft wheat.
Aroma is good and appearance like most wheats is golden. Tastes different than other wheats I have tried over the years but is very good and comes from a good brewery which has many other fine beers.

Pours dull yellow-orange, soapy white head, some lacing.  Aroma of citrus, spice, flowers, but kind of faint.  A balanced taste with citrus, hops, and a bit of bubblegum.  Leaves an interesting kind of sweet coating, almost like honey.  A good creamy/oily mouth.  Refreshing summer beer.

12 fl oz bottle. Yellowish golden with a small haze. Small off-white head. Soft and mellow wheaty nose with a hint of apricots. Medium-bodied and a little oily texture. Fairly neutral flavourwise, but the beer is quite pleasant as it has a little body. Refreshing and easy drinking.
12 oz bottle.  Dull orange color, off white head, great lacing.  Aroma of black pepper and orange rind.  Taste is citrus, malt, light spice, and the barest hint of burnt embers.  Interesting.

Hazy yellow beer.
Low aroma with notes of citrus, wheat and sulphur.
Wheat flavour with some citrus notes and dry, a bit acidic finish.

Aroma: characteristic "wheaty" aroma mixed with a pleasently sour aroma of citrusy origins; Appearance: nothing special to me, just slighly more golden than a traditional American lager; Taste: good initial impression but loses its edge towards the end, very drinkable, and the wheat wins out over the citrus accents, which is a good thing; Palate: better in the beginning, loses fizz quickly; Overall: it is something I could drink a lot of if it were on tap and if I weren’t paying a premium price for it, a good backyard barbeque beer if that makes any sense

Tap. Light grain and herbs for the malt and hops, with some pear and wood notes in the background. Head is small, frothy white with thin lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is slightly hazy, which eventually clears, golden/yellow. Flavor starts slightly sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly acidic. Palate is light, watery and has a soft carbonation. Not bad but nothing outstanding about this Wheat Ale.
Beautiful pour of orange fog with a nice foamy head that lasts. Smells light and a hint of citrus. Taste is real smooth and light, but not a lot there.

20100606 tap at O’Hare.  Pale golden, medium haze, lasting white froth. Nicer looking than your standard American Wheat. Aroma is mildly cascade and light lemony biscuit. Just fine stuff, nicely refreshing. Lingering c-hop bitterness and perfumes.

Bottle.  Aroma has notes of citrus and banana.  Pale yellow clear hue with an average white foamy head that diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is sweet and mild then fades fast.  Palate is very light bodied and watery with decent carbonation.  Overall it tasted more like a macro light beer with some citrus than a craft brewed wheat ale.  Refreshing though.

Had this on tap. Clear with a medium head. Smells of grass, citrus and bannana. Taste crisp mildly sweet. Grain and grass come through on chewing. Medium carbonation which a decent mouth feel. A good example of wheat.
By far my favorite beer. Nice head. Hazy/cloudy appearance, golden. Perfect amount of sweet/bitter.

On tap at their Clybourne brewpub.  A fairly clearn, yellow-gold body with a bleached two inch head in the weizen glass.  The aroma is heavily subdued and I can barely smell a thing.  An incredibly light, near watery mouthfeel with frothy footing that brings her to light-medium body.  The front is smooth, with a tide of carbonation rising on the mid-back end of the palate, tied to a lemony citrus bite that lingers past the fall of the bitterness.  A nice little wheat beer--unimpressive but respectable in its balance.  The story here lies in the bite mid-end.
On tap at brewery near Wrigley.  Slightly hazy golden yellow.  White smallish creamy head.  Aroma of wheat and citrus.  Decent session beer.
On tap at Rattle’n’Hum.  Medium lite cereal grain flavor.  A bit malty and toast-like.  Lite on the hops.
Bottle. Hazy light yellow with white head. Fruity, citrus with some malt. Quite bland but not bad. A bit boring perhaps.

355 ml bottle. From Malmö, Sweden.

Hazy pale golden colour with small white head.
Fruity hoppy wheaty aroma with some sweetness, cereal and hints of rubber. Flavour is fruity hoppy with malty sweetness. Easy but decent Wheat Ale. Smooth.

12 ounce bottle in Hoegaarden tumbler.  Hazy pale yellow with white head and lace. Cereal wheat tangy and citrus aroma.  Fruity peach cereal and wheat tang with mildly bitter finish.  Not horrible.  I’m not sure what the purpose of this style is.  Hence, Bud Golden Wheat.

0.355L bottle from Systembolaget.  Two fingers of dense white head, over a misty, gold/straw colored body.  Modest, clean and dry aroma. Lemony fruitiness and crisp wheaty malts.  Semi-dry, citrus-fruity flavor. Subdued dry maltiness. No hops detected. Not very filling. Lively on the mouth. Dry/sweet fizzy fruit ending. Good quenching abilities, but lack some body and attitude.

Bottle - Pale yellow pour with a nice bubbly white head. Decent grassy hops on the nose, with bubble gum, sweet wheat, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is a bit bigger and grainier than I expected. Thought it’d be sweeter, but the barley malt really comes out and dominates the taste through a long finish. Slightly spicy hops with a mineral water taste in the background. Tastes a bit odd, but it goes down easy.

Bottle. Pours a hazy golden. Aroma is a bit weak, not picking up anything super distinct. Flavor has hints of citrusy fruits, tiny bit bitter, with a nice amount of wheat and yeast, and it pretty fully bodies for a lighter beer. A pretty well balanced brew that is pleasing to the palate. A good summer beer.

Bottle 12fl.oz.
Clear light medium yellow color with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white head. Aroma is light to moderate malty, toasted - wheat, moderate hoppy, perfume, light yeasty, light coriander. Flavor is moderate sweet and light moderate bitter with a average duration. Body is medium to light, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft. [20100417]

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy yellow gold with 3 fingers of fluffy head.



Aroma: Sour dough starter and light fruitiness.



Taste: Toasted wheat, light banana, metallic hop notes and sour dough starter.



Mouthfeel: Full bodied with moderate carbonation.



Overall: Drinkable, but not my bag babe.

Sampled on 4/16/2010. This wheat ale pours a slightly hazy orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is citrusy, cereal and spicy. A medium to light bodied wheat ale. The malts are fruity and cereal. The hops are slightly spicy. A light citrus flavor dominates throughout. There is a touch of hops at the finish as well. Lively carbonation. Light and refreshing taste. Nice summer wheat beer. Good session ale. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Absolutely delicious.  Never had the beer until I moved to Chicago, but it is now one of my favorites.  Pours a cloudy yellow with a thin white head.  Aroma/taste is citrus.  Finish is easy.

Biggish white coarseish head. Cloudy yellow body. Fruity citric wheaty aroma with floral notes. Dry-sweetish floral fruity taste with wheaty citric notes. Mild, dusty mouthfeel. Mid-bodied. Dry fruity citric wehat aftertaste with orangey notes. Incredibly drinkable. (0.33l bottle, Systembolaget, Stockholm.)

Pours light hazy yellow with a moderately sized white head. Aroma is light wheat character, Medium bodied with medium carbonation. Starts off with smooth wheat character - not much else at the beginning. The finish is prickly and somewhat metallic.

Bottle @ Brugmansia/Fonefan Tasting, April 2010. Pours hazy yellow with a creamy white head and lacings. Nose is citrus, herbs and wheat. Lively carbonation. Fresh and dry flavor with notes of orange, wheat and citrus. Medium bodied. Ends very dry.
Barely no head. Light in color. Smell and flavor like a pear soda. Difficult to detect any hops, the bitterness is just symbolic. Not much of a beer. Drink something else.

Somewhat hazy golden with good sized white head... aroma of wheat lemon some very mild spices, more wit aroma than hefe... um, flavor wise, has a light flavor thinish body definitely brings an american macro flavor in the middle, drops the appeal a bit... thin probably good for hot days....

Bottle, 4.2%. Fruity and teaish aroma. Hazy pale yellow colour. Small white head. The flavour is also friuty and teaish, but has a quite watery finish. Flavourful - then watery. Might be refreshing in summer.
pours slightly hazy with a small head, smells kind of fruity. tastes of some wheat, some fruit, not much going on here. easy to drink.

Pours hazy straw pale with a small head that quickly diminishes. Nose is fruity with currant in background. Flavor is a bit cidery with a dry bitter finish. Not so much of a wheat ale but still drinkable.
Bottle at home ... golden yellow ... thin white head ... soft yeasty lemon nose ... again yeasty ... little banana ... fruits ... ok ... bit pely wally ...
En skonsam veteöl som känns grund i både smak och ambition. Här finns goda ansatser, men resultatet är ganska tunt. Anorektisk kropp.

Bottle at home.
Hazy golden coloured with a small white head.
Fruity aroma of hay, caramel and spices.
Fruity flavour of spices and caramel.
Sweet and spicy finish.
Boring.
The aroma is almost medicine like, maybe past it’s prime cheese. There’s a wee bite, and a grassy taste. Astringent finish.

Hazy yellow, white head.  Thin mouthfeel, like a witbeir.  Bit of yeast and malt in the aromas with a distinct citrus aroma.  Pleasant session beer; heck of a lot better for this than macropils, but not too great for anything else.

Bottled:
Pours pale hazy yellow with a green-ish tint. Creamy head. Wheaty citrus aroma. Watery body. Flavour is dry and wheaty with brief notes of yeast and orange.

12oz bottle (screwtop). Fairly decent wheat beer. Pours a hazy golden with a white head. Not alot of character but quite drinkable. A good light summertime brew. Surprised at all the low ratings this one is getting.

Pours a cloudy orange-gold.  Fresh orange-spice aroma.  Flavor is very wheaty with notes of orange and coriander.  Nice little hoppy bite on the finish.  Creamy texture.  Long creamy wheat finish.  Definitely one of my favorite wheat beers.  Corriander isn’t as dominant as others I’ve had and this is has a better texture.  Highly drinkable and a great summer-time beer.

Bottle via the wife.  Could this beer pour any paler yellow>  Thin whispy head. Some very small solids that barely move near the bottom.   Carbonation seems impeded.  Body is light and has the initial tang of wheat but none of the yeastiness,  Sweet, gummy finish. Murgh....
Just another wheat.  That’s all I got.  Chris had one of these that he brought with him from Columbus.  I’m sure they brew better stuff than this.
Little hazy yellow. Thin in both colour and palate. Lots of citrus and some sweet wheat malt. I had high hopes on this. They were not fulfilled.

Pretty ho-hum if you ask me. Cloudy yellow pour. Average nose. Wheat taste. Doesn’t have an over powering of banana that most wheats have. Not horrible, not great. Refreshing but not much else. On tap at 3 Cellars in Franklin, Wisconsin.

Does a "beer" need overwhelming taste and high alcohol content to be considered the best?  312 Urban Wheat may not pack the punch of many other choices, but it does its job exceedingly well: a solid, good-tasting, session beer that I never grow tired of.

A classic for me, perhaps because i’ve been enjoying it for years (and i’ve just recently turned 21).
Cloudy appearance, wheaty aroma, incredibly mild taste.

Not Exceptional, but a solid beer for the fan on a budget, or shopping at a big chain, such as Kroger or Walmart.

Bottle from BoE. Slightly hazy gold with a white head. Aroma is like old fashioned liquid glue with a hint of buttery sweetness. A little sourness in the taste and a mid bitter finish, but to be honest there’s not a lot to get excited about here. So where was the wheat?

Bottled. Pours out in a hazy golden colour with a small creamy white head. Mild aroma of yeast, wheat and lemon-rind. Medium to light-bodied with notes of wheat, neutral yeast, mild citric fruit and biscuits. Edgy mouthfeel due to lively carbonation. Mild finish of wheat, neutral yeast and mild lemon.

Bottle. Yellow, a little hazy colour. White head. Weak aroma of wheat, lemon, light sourness, faint hops. Flavor of wheat, sweet white bread, mild sourness, lemon, faint citrusy hops. Light bodied. A bit boring.
Bottle from a trade with phaleslu. Pours cloudy straw color with white head. Aroma of wheat with some lemon. Wheat flavor. Light to medium body with minimal carbonation. Thanks Peter.

The first whiff is lemon ctirus, then grass and cloves. (No banana, refreshingly.) Some earthy wheat husk. Quite nice.

Appears pale yellow, pillowy white head. Very cloudy with sediment. Good head retention. Minimal lacse, but there is some.

The flavor is acidic citrus at the front of the tongue; earthy grains on the bakc. Very accessible, mild and with not a hint of bitterness.

A smooth, somewhat watery finish. A mildly hopped, earthy brew. Pleasant and balanced. Pretty good.
Pours hazy pale yellow into a tumbler. Bright white head recedes to skim surface. Mild lemon and yeast aromas. Crisp with marshmallow yeast and banana with a mild citrus finish.

Pours golden yellow. Cloudy unfiltered, light citrus taste. Very smooth and easy drinking. This is a good thirst quencher for a hot summer day. Overall, not that exciting or different though. Very similar to Samual Adams Coastal Wheat. If I had to choose between the two, I’d probably opt for the Sam Adams, but overall this is a decent brew.

Bottle.

Slightly hazy light yellow with a quite large white head.

Weak fruity aroma with bread and some citrus.

Flavor was also weak. Reminded much of a lager, bread and some honey. Boring beer that was too watery.

Eagan, Mn. - Old Chicago Pizza - 12 oz bottle. Bright golden pour that turns cloudy after settling.  Snow white head that leaves plenty of lacing. Sweet aroma with hints of lemon drops. Flavor has some hints of banana and cloves. Mouthfeel - thick enough. Overall, a decent wheat.

Bottled.  Clear golden colour, at least I don’t see much of haziness. Might be the haze, höhö. Metal, black tea, and subtle citrusy hops. Light bodied and crisp, really lacking in maltiness and all. Bit of citrusy hops but that’s just l-i-t-t-l-e. Dull beer here, dull style. Body is pretty smooth but what good does that do now?

(Bottle) Pours hazy yellow with a medium sized white head. The aroma is of lemon, orange and apricot alongside mild spicy and honey-like tones. Pale malty and wheat-ish with notes of white bread and grain. Light salty with a touch mild wood, vegetables and herbs. Bit muddy. Hints of wort. The flavour is light sweet, light bitter light acidic. Tones of citrus fruits, watery wheat and mild hops. The mouthfeel is watery and clean with a medium carbonation. “Pale” and dry finish. Bit honey-like in the finish. Light bodied. Light but nice.
Bottle (35 cl) from Systembolaget. Hazy golden, large fluffy white head. Citric aroma with some oranges. Light in body. Slightly sweet, with a medium bitterness.

Bottle, 2010-02-13, Göteborg
AR: citrus, some hops
AP: yellow- light cloudy body, light head
F: apricot, honey, wheat

Bottle: Hazy yellow colour, with a nice creamy white head. Aroma of  fruits, flowers, yeasty and nice sweet maltynes. Flavor was Mild smouth and fresh flowery/fruity mouthfeeling. Grassy and sweet maltynes. Thin body and short fruity finish.

Cloudy light golden colour, medium bubbly white head. Discrete wheat notes in the nose not much else, flavour is the same, and I find it very watery. Mouthfeel is average. This beer is just plain boring.

Bottle, Beers of Europe. Very pale yellow, zingy and zesty and a bit of a German/Belgian crossover, I thought. Refreshing. slightly herby and creamy, with some raspberry flavour lurking in the background. Clean tasting and impressive.
Bottle.  Cloudy golden beer with a fizzy head and body.  The aroma is mainly sweet, and the flavour is malty and yeasty and dry at the finish.  Overall a very plain beer.
Pours yellow with white head, aroma is fruity and ester filled.  Taste is fruity up front and thins into some malt with a kind of lackluster finish that’s slightly sweet.
Top of the heap as Hefe’s go.  Basically tastes like a hefe without being sweet, which makes it great to me.  Good citrus aromas, nice yeast.  Easy to drink with a full yet clean finish.

Bottle tasting at work.
  Not a bad commercial wheat by Goose Island, while this (as their flagship) doesn’t stand up to more finely crafted wheat beers produced for the craft conosuers, it is a wonderful introduction to the craft market for those just getting their feet wet.
  Like New Belgium, Goose Island caters its flagship to the larger consumer market that is still caught up in the (*sigh*) light beer craze. However, delving into their line of products, you find a lot of great beers deserving of the craft culture’s attention.
meh, pretty bland not good flavor. better warm actually. malt is not good, wheat character is not good. Yeast character is bland and not good. A bit harsh actually.
citrusy and fruity with a decent body. it is actually very drinkable and crisp, but it lacks character. a good summer/session brew for those lacking a bit of imagination or motivation.
Bottle from Utobeer. Pale golden, clear, white head. Spicy and malty aroma. Spices take the lead in the mouth. short finish. Best forgotten.
tap: pours cloudy yellow. Arouma of wheat and citrus. Sweet caramel malts. Finishes a bit dry and mildewy. Sharp carbonation, tastes a little stale.

Pours a hazy golden yellow with a small white head.  Very strong citrus, hop smell.  I can definitely taste the wheat beer qualities, but the citrus flavor is a little too overwhelming for my tastes.  Quite a bit of carbonation  and a fairly abrupt finish.  Probably my least favorite goose island beer I’ve had.

lo mismo que el aleman, esperaba mas
Bottle: clear for a wheat, light, slight maltiness. Refreshing. Food Pairing: Green salad. Thanks to rcasta.
Bottle: clear for a wheat, light, slight maltiness. Refreshing. Food Pairing: Green salad. Thanks to rcasta.

Clear pale yellow color with a good sized foamy head.  Aroma of lightly spiced wheat and citrus.  Flavor is sweet and spicy yeast and a lemony citrus bitterness.  Light bodied but still feels oddly thick on the palate.  All in all a good beer.
Aroma of wheat and hops.  Flavor consists of earthy citrus, wheat malts, and a slightly hoppy finish.  A good beer, but nothing unique here.

On tap at Tilted Kilt. Pours semi-hazy yellow with a big white head. Creamy and wheaty malt nose, not much else going on. Flavor matches. I guess I like the fact that it’s an American wheat instead of a weizen, but still not my thing. I might look at this beer differently if it wasn’t 8 degrees outside. Maybe I’ll give it another shot come summertime.

Bottle.  Hazy gold and yellow with a medium head.  Aromas are pineapple with caramel and wheat.  Lemon with yeast and soft spices.  Flavours are sweet tropical fruit with gentle lemon bitterness.  Has a nice spritzy, yeasty palate.  Decent.
Bottle. Golden pour with white head. Spicy wheat flavor... Slight sweetness but mainly wheat and malt characteristics. Where is the hop presence?

Bottle:  Pours a pale straw color with a large white head.  Not much aroma present, faint notes of wheat and malt.  The flavor is a sweet malt base with light wheat notes and a little floral hoppiness in the tail.  A tame crispness in the finish.  Rather mild, yet good.
Pours out golden with a little bit of suspended sediment. Small, white head. Aroma is pretty light, with wheat notes. Taste is the same. Pretty weak, but wheat flavored.
Light yellow, white head. Wheaty, spice aroma.  Taste is more spiciness, sourish wheat, fruity.

Draught at the White Horse American Beer Festival, July 2009. Pale gold. Maybe a hint of yeast but not really very much going on. Easygoing and straightforward with no great character. Sweetish. May have shown better on its own rather than surrounded by a bunch of much bigger US beers. Not really a very inspired choice to bring over for a US festival but I guess they needed something for the normal Sloaney Pony punters.

Draught @ Fire Rock Grille in Des Moines: &nbsp Pale straw, faint haze, fairly clear otherwise, thin white sudsy head, dies quickly leaving sparce lacing. &nbsp Carbonation seems nil. &nbsp Weak straw and grass nose. &nbsp Wheat aspect is faint. &nbsp I was told this was a light wheat ale? &nbsp Sure seems that way. &nbsp Rather grassy on the tongue but also wheaty. &nbsp Faint mealiness, but its not bad. &nbsp Seems like a watered down American Wheat, which probably what they were going for. &nbsp Not bad, good on a hot day. &nbsp Problem being its not hot,  but may 28F. &nbsp Anyways, a little corny on the backside, in addition to the straw and grass. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel. &nbsp Certainly not like a regular wheat. &nbsp Meh...
Refrigerated bottle poured into a glass.  It pours a hazy yellow with little head and some lacing.  The taste is musty yeasty wheat and sour spicy hops.  Not very good.
12oz - Cloudy straw color, no head but some lace.  Orange and bread dough on nose.  Doughy yeast is the main flavor, but overall this is very mild.  Not bad, just unimpressive.
Bottled. Poured a faintly cloudy yellow with a very small fizzy head. Sort of like a bland wheat with a very clean finish.  Sessionable. if you’re into that kin of thing.

Bottle 355  ml  

Appearance:  filtered wheat , or just slightly filtered ?. Mostly clean, not crystal golden brew with mid white top.        
                                                             Nose:  dusty , pepper like feel ,bit musky , husky with golden grain.   
                           Flavor/Palate :  mid light bodied , slight citric sourness with grainy , wheat like accents. Soft ending. Easy going sloppy work. Sight feel of leafy hops. Bah.
all the common characteristics of a wheat beer with a great flavor - I like it with a lemon - lighter than some wheat beers
Bottle.  Pours light gold and cloudy.  The thin white head quickly dissipated.  Floral hop and wheat aroma.  Floral hop, wheat, and citrus/lemon flavor.  Medium body and carbonation.

Cask Stillage from the Jug at the GABF, Colorado Convention Center 24/09/2009
Floral aroma. White head. Golden coloured smooth and creamy on the palate with a crisp and dry malt finish.

Location: 12 oz bottle from jcos, 11/12/09




Aroma: It has an aroma of citrus, wheat, spice, and honey


Appearance: Pours a hazy straw yellow color with a bubbly white head


Flavor: Taste is similar to the nose, spice, wheat, lemon, and honey


Palate: It has an unexciting mouthfeel with a light amount of body


Overall Impression: 
Not the most exciting beer.  It isn’t bad, but it just isn’t really memorable or exciting.  I really don’t have to say much more on this beer, it is what one might expect.
Light lemony haze with a cute white foam.  Light honey aroma.  Light honeyed malt flavours Hints of nutmeg and very little hop.  Smooth and drinkable as hell.

On draft at The Happy Gnome. Pale gold in colour with a bit of haze and medium carbonation. Aromas are of flowers, peach, and a bit of wheat. Quite tart in the mouth, with notes of quince, lemon, and malted wheat. Fruity and a bit simple, but could provide some nice refreshment on a hot day.
bottle.  Pours yellow and flat.  Aroma of some hay, grass, wheat.  Flavor is some spice, wheat, apple, understated. Thin and fizzy, not that great.

12oz bottle from VIllage Beer Merchant.  Hazy yellow pour with fading white head.  Aroma is nothing special to me....typical citrusy grain wheat beer aroma.  Flavor is along the same lines but with a decent hoppy snap to accompany the decent sweet grain finish.  If it were even hoppier, perhaps it might set itself apart.....but overall, a decent easy drinking wheat beer, especially on a hot day.

Poured from bottle into tall glass.

Medium gold that is slightly hazy from the yeast. The yeast particles are very small and produce a nice sparkle effect. Some lacing but not much head.

Major lemon smell, with some sweet wheat malt and light orange hops.

Not a lot of taste but what is there is mostly nice. Citrus flavor overall - both lemon and orange, with some wheatiness, but not too much. However, it is slightly too sweet for me considering the style.

Pretty high carbonation and light body.

Pretty good for a summer day. Nice example of an American Wheat.

Bottle at Navy Pier. Pours a light opaque color typical of a wheat ale. Aroma is citrusy and hoppy but a little more doughy/stale than expected. Flavor was very mild and bitter with some sweet/spicyness. Nothing really too special. Palate is unremarkable. Not too great but its worth a try when in Chicago.

Bottled. A hazy golden beer with a thin white head. The aroma has notes of wheat and oranges. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, wheat, and oranges, leading to a dry wheaty finish. The body is light. An uninteresting and forgetable beer.

I used to like this one, but then realized it was not all that good.  It is a watered down american wheat.  If you like the style of american wheat then this might be okay for you.  The malts just did not come through for me.
Pours a cloudy yellow color with a little white head. Not much lacing. Wheat smell but not overally aromatic. Lacked in flavor and was little more tart than other wheats I’ve had.

Draft sample at GABF 2009.  Hazy straw color with a small white head.  Aroma is pale malt, wheat, citrus, and mild hops. Flavor is nicely balanced pale malt and wheat along with a slight citrusy hop kick and light spice.  Palate is light and refreshing.  This is not bad at all for a wheat ale.

EXIT 2018: Flavor has been annihilated by AB-InBev. Now tastes like Budweiser with mild wheat notes and a finish like unflavored LaCroix. Reduced from a 3.2 to a 2.0. Dis gaaahhbage

Bottle, 355ml - Hazy pale yellow beer with almost no head. Aroma is fruity with notes of tropical fruits, passion fruits and pineapple. Flavor is fruity with notes of tropical fruits. Light bodied but very refreshing.

Re-rate as the previous one was kinda bogus.  Purchased at Binnys in Chicago, IL for my 30th birthday party, enjoyed during a summer heat wave.  Appearance is almost wit-like, very very light straw yellow, cloudy, with slightly frothy white head.  Aroma of wheat, a very small hint of sweetness, also light malts.  Flavor is kinda weird, goes down very crisp and great on a hot summer day, but it feels like it’s missing something.  Very straw like in flavor and body, I do enjoy but mainly in situations where no other brew is available.
Bottle at SBWF 2009. Yellow, small white head. Malty aroma with wheat. Spicy flavor, wheat, malty and quite thin.

Cloudy, pale gold appearance with an average size head and little lacing.   Subdued, wheaty, lemongrass aroma.  Thin on the palate with a weak, wheatish, slightly fruity/citric taste.  Light to medium bodied, decently carbonated mouthfeel with a short lived finish.  Not a drainpour, but little to recommend.
Tap.  Very light yellow color.  White head., very nice lacing.  Not much aromatics.  Some light wheat.  Boring.  Flavor is a sweet wheat malt.  Well balanced.  a crisp hop finish.  Hints of lemon.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy light straw yellow color with a thin, fizzy head.  Light lemon zest and grassy aroma.  Flavor is a little lacking, but I can pick up some light traces of wheat and lemon in the finish.  Very watery texture with lively carbonation.  Refreshing but not the most flavorful offering.

Far superior to all those "rural wheat ales" 
Pours a fluffy medium head with some lace and a lightly hazy yellow color. The aroma is yeasty with some citrus rind. The flavor is lemony yeasty and lightly spicy.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.  The look is clear, golden in color, with a white colored head.  The smell is wehat, light, chex mix, and a little citrus.  The taste is is wheat, citrus, light, and simple.
Pretty brew, but bland! Light cloudy straw color. Good body. Some tangy flavor, but little hop bitterness.

Bomber bottle, pours a clear yellow gold with a white head, aromas of faint malt and bread, little hops on the nose, faint flavors of malt and bread, light hop bitterness at the finish, mouth feel is pretty light on the palate, a pretty simple so-so beer from Goose Island.

Appearance: 3/5
It poured a hazy yellow liquid with a small white foam.

Smell: 4/10
A very weak smell with a hint of banana and candy.

Taste: 3/10
Very weak smell, some bread and sweetness.

Mouthfeel: 2/5
Medium smooth with a medium carbonation and a light body.

Comment:
This is a watery and boring wheat beer with very little flavour and aroma. The big question is, where is the wheat? This tastes mostly like a pale lager.

I figured this would be a good match with most kinds of food. So I tried it with some rolls of minute steak filled with pesto, mozarella and gorgonzolla served in a creamy sauce with rice on the side. It wasn’t a good match at all, the beer got a very odd bitter taste and the food also taste worse. Maybe it was the cheeses that created the weird combo but I think this beer is best on it’s own.

I’m raising my score a bit since the beer is drinkable and doesn’t have any bad tastes. But there are better options out there if you crave some wheat beer. If you are more in the mood for lager (as this beer taste like) then there are better lagers available as well.

Slightly hazy yellowish pour.  The nose is lightly lemony and wheaty with a little bit of light berryish estery sweetness.  Pretty simple brew really.  Light wheaty palate with just a kiss of light crackery malt.  There isn’t much to this one, but it isn’t terrible either.
Bottle. Pours pale gold with a white head. Wheaty aroma, some sweetness and some citrus. The flavor is wheaty and grainy with light citric notes. Refreshing and accessible.
This beer was a major disappointment.  There are so many wheat beers that blow this slop off the bar....
A nice clean and easy to drink wheat beer for the masses, complete with separate marketing from other GI products.  Not bad; nothing special.
Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Light gold in color with a small white head. Aroma is of wheat. Taste is of wheat, grain and citrus.
[Tap] An entirely delicious beer. Cloudy yellow pour, tastes of deliciousness and  light orange with hops and yeast. Mild head that hung around for a while. Very very good.

Draft.  Pours a cloudy yellow.  Small white head.  Some lacing.  Mild citrus aroma.  Flavor of yeast and citrus.  Overall this is a nice wheat beer.  Not on par with Oberon (Bells) or Whitson (Arcadia) yet a good easy drinking summer beer.  Hard to go anywhere in Chicago where this isn’t on tap.  Not every beer can be critically acclaimed, but Goose Island had done a fantastic job marketing this (312 = Chicago area code) and I am sure this beer rules the market.
FCBF 09  It was great to have a wheat beer during this hot brewfest.  Nice color, light and citrus flavor.

FCBF 09.  We went back for more stout, it was gone, but at least they replaced it with another of their beers we hadn’t tried, this one.   Pale color with a full head.  Light palate but still a nice delicate taste.
Living in Chicago, I have had to get use to this local beer. Can’t complain.

(draft @ 2009 Flour City Brewer’s Fest - Frontier Field - Rochester, NY) Clear yellow pour with a light white head. Aroma is dry and grainy with some very light citrus and yeast. Flavor is much the same. Very dry at the front with a light citrus and some spice notes. Almost tastes like a witbier.
Aroma is floral hops.  Flavor is similar, with some citrus fruit.  Not much to this beer but not bad for drinking for refreshment.

22oz bomber. I couldn’t help but try one of these eventually. As my nickname is Blaze312 it seemed like a good idea. Pours a watery piss yellow color. Little head that eventually disappears. Aroma is wheat and slight hops. Taste is very comparable.
bottle thanks to ericandersnavy.  very pale yellow with a white head. wheat and light fruit on the nose.  little thin on the palate with a light lemon flavor in the finish.

(Re-rate) 12 oz. bottle. Weird to see "Goose Island, Fort Collins, CO" on the label now. This is everywhere now and will be even more places when they start rolling out new area codes. Pours a somewhat cloudy gold color with a medium white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus, sweet dough, and mild spice. Flavor is the same, albeit without a hint of any spice. Just wheat and citrus. Very light. Moderate carbonation, some sweetness. When I’m at a wedding or ballgame and have limited options, this will do just fine.

Bottle at Monks Sveavagen, Stockholm.

Pours hazy golden with a white wet head.

Wheat and light spicy aroma.
Wheat flavour, uncomplicated smooth mouthfeel.

Good for this warm summers day
An OK golden ale - nondescript. Doesn’t make itself known as a wheat beer  - very light esters and a bit of sweetness, but no strong character. Drinkable, but forgettable.
Come on, this was not cloudy, nor did I detect Cascade hops.  I must have had a different 312.

Pours bright golden with a 2-inch white head that settles slowly.  The ale has a very slight haze and the haze aside, looks like a pilsner. The lacing is very modest.  Hints of hops in the nose.  Light on the palate. Light body. An unexpected, and to me undesirable after-taste. The unpleasant, but yet unidentified aftertaste lingers.  Fortunately, the after taste is light as well. Carbonation is moderate.  The wheat characteristics are barely perceptible. This is a light ale and may appeal to many for that reason. I find it a decent summer, quaffing beer, but wish it had more to offer than the pervasive lightness (carbonation, nose, body, and flavor).

a hazy gold beer under a medium sized sudsy white head.  palate is light and crisp with a good bit of tingly carbonation.  a typical, fairly tasteless, american wheat.  not hopped up or anything.  they stuck with the textbook here.
12oz bottle today at Brickskellar, one of the few beers I knew I hadn’t had.  Pours yellow with a bright white ring.  Nose is sweet, wheaty, and light.  Taste was sweet, light and just ok.

Bottle. Straw color, very nice lacing. Fairly straightforward American wheat with some tanginess to it, low hops ( I didn’t notice the Cascades), light body. Refreshing. Recommended if you like the style.

On tap at White Horse, Parsons Green.  Very pale gold, greenish tinge, thin white head.  Not a huge aroma, touch of soap on the hop, but really refreshing beer.  Bit dullish, little bit of lemon edge to it, more an American wheat than a wit.  Not very exciting but very refreshing.

Source:12 oz bottle from a sixer purchased at Chuck’s in BG. 

Glass:Weizen. 

Appearance:Hazy gold pour with a two finger white head.  

Aroma:Wheat and clove with a hint of citrus. 

Flavor:Clove dominates with yeast and wheat present. 

Palate:Medium/light body with solid carbonation.

Overall:OK for a wheat ale.  Not in the ranks of Oberon or Gumballhead, but OK.
On tap at the White Horse, Parsons Green, 3rd July 09. Cloudy golden yellow. Uninspiring and dull.
Pours a cloudy golden color. Not quite as sour or as fragrant as most wheat beers I’ve tried. It’s a bit more restrained. Good accompaniment to food.
Cask at American beer fest White Horse. Cloudy yellow ale with medium head. Citrus, wheat summer beer. Rather bland beer lacking in complexity.

A Mes rate: cask handpull at the Sloany Pony.
Pale yellow with a thin white film. Faint citrus and yeast, some boring malt, lots of pondwater. Bloody hell. Rank. As the commercial description says, "not like any other Goose Island beer". Most of them are decent, some superb. This however was not either.
(bottle). Pours a cloudy gold color. Medium white head which is mostly diminishing. Wheat aroma and flavor with light lemon. Avg duration. Thin texture. Spare lacing. Soft carbonation.

Bottle 12 oz. Pours bright yellow, clear, little sediment.  Bright white glistening head, 1.5 inches.  Beautiful appearance, but short longevity and little lacing.  Light aroma, lemon and citrus, similar taste. Thin for a wheat ale.

On tap. Slightly cloudy yellow with a small white head doesn’t retain very well. Light nose of wheat, yeast, and very slight hops. Taste is also light and resembles a yeasty pale lager. Light carbonation and decent moutfeel. Easy drinker, but not great.
Heavier beer. Smooth but also has a bitter taste. It’s fizzy but not in a bad way. Citrusy and good for casual drinking.

A cloudy pale yellow beer with a decent white that manages to leave some good lacing.  Sweet aroma of wheat, apricot and oranges.  So far the beer gushes cool refreshing summer beer.  Light citrus flavor and wheat.  Mild carbonation hits the tongue and the beer finishes with a light citrusy wheat bite at the end.  There is not much to this beer but it is easily drinkable and enjoyable.

A really bad example of a wheat ale...I had no clue the style before drinking and then thought it was a pale lager.  Piss colored but at least had some lacing.  Aroma was yeasty, skunky and lemony...it was ok.  Flavor was slightly bitter but like in a bud way...fizzy, thin and just overall bad on the palate but not the worst.

Lemon and slightly dusty aroma, with a a thin yellow appearance. Mouth feel is very thin. Has a decent burst of fruity flavor at first, but dissipates very quickly with no lasting finish. Disappointingly one-note in flavor with little complexity.
An ok effort.  Just letting it sit for a few minutes and warm up made it much worse.  All of a sudden got a little woddy flavor to it and then dissipated.  For Goose Island, I’m let down.
Pours a slightly cloudy yellow.  Aroma of wheat with a hint of vanilla and soap.  A very light flavored beer with hints of yeast.  Not really that exciting.

On tap at Shorty’s.  This central Chicago themed brew is advertised as "President Obama’s favorite beer."  Pour is a transparent but slightly hazed golden color.  Taste is lager with subtle hop and wheat.  Thin on the body.  Refreshing and enjoyable but someone needs too tell Mr. President, there are a lot better beers out there..
Nice cloudy golden body with a thin white head, this wheat has a clean yet more fulsome body, bit of lemon zest and banana, than many.  Very refreshing on a mild day.

bottle from flssmrbrewalum... bottled 11/25/08

pours a hazy lemonade color with a vibrant white head and some sporadic spotty lacing. 

the nose is dusty... notes of earthy almost savory yeast, hay, lemon and rust. 

the flavor profile is pretty much the same with the addition of banana and red apples in the aftertaste.

thin to medium bodied with a prickly mouth feel. refreshing pool side beer...6/3/6/3/14/3.2

Pours cloudy, pale yellow. Thin white head with good lacing. Aroma is wheat grain and citrus. Flavor is crisp with barley, wheat and a citrus. The citrus is very notable in the after taste. A very light and refreshing beer. A good cook out beer.

I’m kind of surprised the ratings are so low on this. I’m not a big fan of wheat ales by any means but this one seemed to have a few things going for it that others in they style have failed for me. For one thing the pour was nice with a large white head that actually lasted for once, nice lacing on the glass. The aroma while light of hay and straw also provided a slight fruity sweetness that was inviting. The taste is light and crisp in the mouth with yeast and wheat combining for a light doughy taste, really it was almost pastry-like due to the subtle fruity sweetness this beer provides. Lastly, the bitch actually had some hops to speak of and left you with a decent finish considering the style. Very well blanced in my opinion between the wheat and yeast you would expect, as well as a touch of fruit and hops. Not bad and very refreshing to boot. This one is underrated if you ask me.

transparent yellow beer that is overly carb’d. aroma is practically nil, very neutral with a touch of malt sweetness. flavor is along the same lines and lacking in complexities. refreshing or thirst quenching are not valid defenses for this beer in my eyes.

A lightlly hazed blonde with a thick white head. In aroma, a lightly chalky malt, grainy, wheaty with light berry notes. In mouth, a fresh grainy ale with light berries, light and refreshing. On tap at Clybourn, May 17 2009.

650 ml. bottle. Shared with Marilyn. Pours a thin head, with attractive lacing, over a pale yellow (SRM 5) body......nose of light bread, light malt.....taste is dry throughout, light wheaty taste, light yeast, minimal spice.....mouth feel is light. Light , minimal spice, refreshing but not a great wheat ale.
From tap in a local Chicago bar. Off aroma but ok wheatbear taste. Not my favourite style and this one is drinkable.
Golden hue, cloudy/hazy. Large white head that dissipates rapidly, no lacing. Very slight citrus nose. Flavor is crisp citrus, bread, dough and fruit.  Body is light yet creamy, soft carbonation.
Good wheat beer good color and it has a pretty good clarity for a wheat beer
Bottle.  Pours a pale, orange gold color with a large white head.  No good aroma or taste to note.  Notes of orange and bread, but mild and light.  A very light tasting wheat ale.  Very thin palate

Golden, clear with nice white head.  Faint orange citrus aroma.  Light and flat on the palate, slightly creamy, light grain flavor.  For a lighter beer this has a full feel on the tongue.  On tap at Dive 96
Tap @ Y Bar, Kalamazoo. Hazy golden colour, white head. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Flavour has wheat, yeast and fruits.

Bottle: Hazy light golden with a dense white film of head. Fresh wheaty aroma with lots of grassy notes- crackery dry wheat and grassy hops. Thin and a bit fizzy in texture- pale bread crust flavor in the background with a light watery wheat character. Not much depth or bitterness with a straw note. Feels macro-ish, but with no major flaws or off flavors.

Appearance:  light golden yellow; mild haze; starts with big fluffy white head, but dissipates quicker than it should

Aroma:  light wheat character; slight malt presence; very marginal hop presence by way of citrus

Flavor:  moderate, refreshing wheat; very light malt sweetness faint in the background; slightly crisp on an above-average finish

Mouthfeel:  medium-light body; medium-high carbonation

Overall:  not an attention grabber, but within the wheat category, this is definitely better than a "2.77" beer

Overall, not a bad beer. I don’t tend to drink wheat beers much, so I don’t have much to compare it against. Biggest strike against it might be that the hops do most of the talking, which is not exactly what you’d expect in a wheat ale.
1st rating - I really liked this beer. Not the best aroma, but it went down smooth. Kind of citrus taste. Quite enjoyable.
Pour from a 22oz bottle. Hazy blond brew with one finger of slightly creamy head. Modest aroma of wheat with slight citrus overtones. Mild flavor and body.  Inoffensive, not much more to say.

Draught. Pours a hazy golden color with a medium foamy white head. Nose of wheat, yeast, fruits,  little banana. Initial taste of mild wheat, citrus, banana. Watery body, belove average palate duration, too simple one dimensional not challenged wheat ale. Average head retention and light body. Overall not impressed.
12 oz pours a hazy yellow with a foamy head.  Big fruity aroma.  Soft body with yeasty taste, some wheat and some fruits at the end.  Decent lawnmower beer.
i was a little let down with this one. this wheat beer was clear. the beer is not filtered but it is over centrifuged!  missing the yeast taste.
refreshing wheat beer.  a good bbq beer.  and girls seem to enjoy it.  not too bad
Pours a hazy yellow with a thin white head. Aroma of citrus. Tastes of wheat, citrus, fruit, hops, and other sweet notes. Drinkable and an all right beer overall.

22ozBottle. A slightly hazy golden color whit a two finger white lasting head. Aroma is a little lemon grass,some light bready yeast, and a touch of spice,very faint banana.Flavor is subtle, light wheat malt,some faint citrus fruit,bubblegum and a little bready yeast, some sort of light spice notes but all very balanced and subtle. Very drinkable, a geed summer and session brew.

on tap.  A mostly clear yellow hue with a nice white head that had little retention.  Aroma was of citrus, spicy and a slight banana note.  Flavor was light but well balanced between fruity malt notes and bread notes. Finish was smooth.  Carbonation was a little elevated but did not negatively effect the beer.
