bottle thanks to boomer0813.  poured a clear yellow with a thin white head.  aroma of citrus, banana, and slight clove.  flavor was citrus and thats about it.  light almost non-apparent body with high carbonation.

12 oz bottle: Aroma is wheat, lemons, a little grassy, and a light hoppiness.  Appearance is a very clear yellow pour with a medium sized white head that lingers for quite a while.  Taste is acidic, with lemon citrus coming to the forefront, some wheat textures intermingled, and a bit of that chewing gum flavor.  Palate is really easy drinking,  quite carbonated on the tongue, and the aftertaste has a wheat note to it.  Overall, On a hot summer day this would be pretty key, but as a wheat overall I think this one is lacking in some categories.  Cheers!

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a hazy bright yellow with min. white fizzy head. Aroma of faint citrus, very faint banana, musty, soap. Flavor of light wheat, faint citrus, faint bubblegum, not much taste here. Mouthfeel is light body and high carbonation. Overall, good poolside session beer for the summer.
Very smooth with nice taste of wheat grain.  Slight citrus notes also apparent.

The bottle pours a hazy yellowish golden color with a small, foamy, snow white head.  The foam settles quickly to a thin film, leaving minimal spots behind on the glass.  The aroma is fairly mundane, with notes of fresh wheat, light cereal grains, and pale malt showing strongest.  There is a wisp of floral hop character, along with a drop of honey sweetness.  Flavors follow suit, light and clean but boring overall.  Basically just wheat and honeyed pale malt.  The palate falls somewhere between thin and medium bodied, with balanced carbonation and a lightly prickly, semi-dry finish.  Sessionable on a hot summer’s day, but boring overall.  Decent tailgate beer.

On tap at the Peekskill Brewery.  Pours a clear light yellow with a nice soft white head.  Aroma is wheat, with a touch of lemon.  Thin bodied with a lot of active carbonation.  Mostly empty flavor wise.  Finishes lightly with a touch of wheat, a hint of banana, and a little bit of lemon.  Pretty clean, but lacking much substance.

Pours slightly hazed pale yellow with a tall pillowy white head that has o.k. retention. Aroma is banana, white bread and a touch of lemon. Flavor is sweet grain, honey wheat, banana, and some fruity ester notes. Palate is thin and watery but very crisp and refreshing. Nice refreshing, though ultimately boring wheat.
Nice wheat beer.  Gold color pour.  Hint of banana, wheat and hops. Small white color head.  Aroma is wheat and hops.
Poured a very pale yellow with a crisp white head. The aroma has a very apparent wheat smell and overall it is a very good beer.
Bottle.  Pours a golden yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is wheat malt and hops.  Flavor is very weak but consists of mostly malt and fruit.  Average wheat beer.
Bottle and Draft.  yellow-gold color with a thin white head. Aroma: wheat, slight fruit, and a touch of malt. Flavor: Mild wheat, hops and slight fruit.

Bottle.  Bottled on date:  12/23/08.  Pours a hazy gold with tons of little floaties and a HUGE white head.  Subtle aroma features wheat, lemons, bananas, bubble gum, vanilla, some spiciness, and hints of corn.  Thin-bodied.  Starts with some grainy corniness.  Finishes with a crisp biscuity dryness and some lemons.  Refreshing at least.
BOTTLE: pours a hazy yellow, mild aroma of grain and fruit. Lemon/orange on taste, with some carbonation. Pretty good wheat beer.
Bottled. Hazy yellow in color. Aroma is somewhat grainy with a little fruitiness. Grainy flavors with a little bit of yeastiness. Fairly crisp and easy to drink. Not bad for a wheat ale.

I have to love a beer dedicated to chicago.  Pours light hazy straw yellow, with thin white fizz.  Flavors of banana, pineapple, and slight malts come across, with a finish thats sweet an lemony.  This is a great wheat beer.

Out of a bottle. Had a hazy yellowish color with a pretty sweet aroma. Tasted pretty good, not like most wheat beers (which was a plus for me). It was pretty crisp and was extremely drinkable. Definitely a beer that I will get again.

220z bomber.  Hazy orange-yellow color.  Subdued aroma, a little sweet wheat and malt.  The taste is solid, not unlike a Bavarian Hefe, but without the banana yeast characteristics.  Some light lemony tang.  Excellent full mouthfeel, while still relatively light on the palate.  Crisply balanced by the hops, this is quite refreshing and easy drinking.
12 ounce bottle purchased from Archer Liquors in Chicago, IL for $1.55 Not bad.

Pours a cloudy orange slash golden color
taste of fruit and a hint of hops
not my favorite wheat beer however it is drinkable

Slightly hazy orange coloured body with a thin white head. Aroma of wheat, orange, coriander seed and a little lemon. Medium-bodied; Strong carbonation with a nice malty finish. Aftertaste shows some sweetness, but shows good character throughout. I sampled this twelve ounce bottle purchased from Fox & Abel in Chicago, Illinois on 07-August-2005.
This is one of my favorite beers. Its refreshing but not too light, flavorful but not overpowering. it has the right balance of all that a wheat beer should. This is one of my beer staples..
Yellow pour with a white head.  Aroma of malts and citrus.  Flavor of mostly malts with some orange coming in.  I didn’t feel that it held up to the hype.

On tap at Chigaco Midway airport.  Consumed two, served in frosty pint glasses, around 12pm.  Aroma was barely noticable, but some hops and graininess present.  Had a light yellow color but strangely hazy appearance.  The flavors were more like a rather intense pilsner or helles, not anything too reminiscent of wheat.  I enjoyed this beer thoroughly, I was surprised by how much flavor and delicate bready graininess it possessed.  I ordered this one because it was the only "local brew" on the menu.  That’s what the servers told me anyway.  It was pretty dang good, I wish I could get my hands on it, I’d like to get a few six packs to work on...

Not bad at all. It’s not anything to write home about, but it’s a solid choice if you want a wheat beer. I’d prefer Hoegaarden for sure, but if you’re in the midwest, some 312 wouldn’t be a bad choice.

On tap at (do not laugh) TGI Fridays in Chicago by Midway Airport.
Pours a clear pale gold with a nice fruity/wheat aroma.
Flavour has a definite fruity lemon like hook to the wheat body and light grassy hop.
Went very well with JD BBQ Steak and Onion Rings...

There’s a reason that Goose Island took this off their seasonal list and started brewing it year round. Their description of 312 as having "densely populated flavor" is definitely accurate. There’s a lot more depth of flavor than most wheat bears, but it still remains quite refreshing despite having a slightly bitter aftertaste.
Has a hazy look to it with slight head. A very nice and easy to drink beer for me. Has a slight lemon twist to it. not a very complex beer at all but a nice every day drinking beer.

Pours hazy light straw color with a small white head. Faint nose, light fruit and grassy hops. Similar flavor, light and crisp, somewhat hoppy with some lemon and grass. This is an easy to drink beer, would be a little better if the flavors were more prominent.
Decent beer. Tastes fruity and pours with little head. Not very complex but fairly enjoyable. Not much aftertaste
Poured a golden hazy light color with little head.  Aroma was fairly minimal.  Overall a nice, easy drinking beer.
Bottle. Pours a hazy yellow color, almost no head. Aroma is sweet, grass, and some malts. Taste is spice and hpos. A decent wheat beer.

Boring straw yellow pour with little head.  Lots of carbonation.  Weak scent, hard to pick up, slightly sweet and a bit hoppy?
Much deeper taste then expected.  A uniquely sweet and deep hops taste.  I’m guessing it’s the Goose Island Hops, actally I’m hoping it is as it’s rather good and I picked up another beer form the same brewery.  Suprisingly clean finish.  The carbonation isn’t nearly as bad in the mouth.  A nice easy to drink beer with a good deep sweet flavour.  Would be a nice session beer.

actually reminds me of a couple of goose islands other fine beers particularly matilda and the pere. tastes and body are quite acceptable to me. sweet and just a touch syrupy with a nice touch of hops and yes it is loaded with character fruity and somewhat spicy actually more of a chemical type spice flavor. a pure type of brew it is vibrant and interesting.

Pours a a hazy golden color with minimal, fizzy white head. Aroma is malt, citrus, wheat, and spice. Decent aroma for such a basic beer. Taste is a very earthy wheat, with malt, lemon, and a nice spiciness underneath. Afar better alternative to macros if you want to get tanked. Nothing spectacular though, just an easy drinking beer.

Pour: Cloudy pale yellow with a thin white head.
Nose: wheat orange lemon malt grass
Taste: Slightly hoppy hints of wheat and lemon. 
Finish: Hoppy on the front a bit coarse through the end.
Overall: it is an okay beer Goose Island has made better beer than this. It has a nice flavor that is thin and unrefined.

Bottle. Pours cloudy soft gold with foamy white head.  Smells citrusy and semi floral with hints of some spice.  Tastes spicy like cloves and some citrus.  Bitter aftertaste that doesnt match the beer.  Overall, its pretty good.

Draught @ Rebo’s - Pours almost clear yellow, small white head...aroma is bread and yeast, slight citrus...flavour follows, light bitterness, not too much going on...my first GI beer, not that great, watery on the back end...looking forward to other beers...

(10/9/08) Draught sample at the brewpub in Clybourn, Chicago. Slightly hazy golden. Fruity aroma with hops, flowers, some citrus and light wheat notes. Flavor starts a bit sweetish and fruity with some yeast and a bit of wheat and bread notes and finishes with mild hoppy bitterness. Light to medium-bodied. Not bad.

On tap.   Tastes slightly spicey, a little like coriander, yeasty, and a sligfht touch of citrus.  Some lacing on the glass, pours a clear yellow.  One of the better wheat beers I’ve had from the United States.
bottle. has a sweet citrusy aroma. pours a light yellow with a thin yellow head. has a bit of an orange and wheat taste. not too bad.

Aroma: Faint yeast mustiness, not much going on here.  Appearance: Pale gold, hazy with visibly suspended sediment.  No head, only some white bubbles.  Flavor:  Lemon, wheat, and dust.  No off flavors, but somewhat boring.  Palate: Clean, crisp, and drinkable.
Nothing impressive. All my friends recommended it so I tried it and I don’t think that is is worth the hype.
Not much here at all.  I could drink it so it wasn’t a total bomb.  Light hazy color.  Fairly bland taste.
This was a very disappointing outing from Goose Island.  Had on tap.  Yellow color with little head.  Pretty watery with little flavor.
Bottled. Hazy and pale golden in colour with a small white head. Wheaty with notes of banana, citrus, spices and has a thin mouthfeel.
Bottled@SBWF2008. Hazy yellowish colour, small white head. Aroma is wheat, mild spices and some slight notes of stomach acids. Flavour is wheat, some spices, mild yeast and rather acidic. Watery.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Hazy golden with a basically absent head. Light yeasty aroma. Light-bodied with slightly sweet malts and a wee fruitiness. No bitterness. Very thin and a poor excuse for a beer. 190908

Citrus, spice and wheat aroma wafts over the foamy white head and cloudy straw color of this unfiltered wheat ale. Mouthfeel is very creamy with clove, wheat and citrus flavors finsihing with a slighty hoppy aftertaste. Very refreshing and pairs well with light snacks and/or a picnic food.
Cloudy golden with tiny white head. Sweet yeasty aroma with fruity and wheat notes. Flavour likewise with hints of spice. Finishing sweet.
Very light wheat beer.  Not a whole lot of flavor, very clear.  Could drink a lot of this during a hot day.  Refreshing beer.

On tap and very fresh tasting. Kind of a very light and crisp wheat beer. simple back ground of citrus. these wheat beers are getting old as a whole, but this isn’t a bad beer to have with dinner on a summer night.

Bottle. Light gold in color with lots of carbonation. Small white head. Aroma is grassy and hops. creamy palate. Flavor is more hop than wheat. I’m not a big fan of wheat beers but I like this one. They didn’t go overboard on the wheat.

Pours a cloudy light gold in color.  About a half inch of head on the pour, but it’s quickly gone.  Smell is spicy, but off slightly.  Taste is hoppy, but rather BMC’ish.  Highly carbonated in the mouthfeel.  Refreshing, but not good enough to warrant another purchase.

I really want to like this beer, unfortunately it’s a rare miss from Goose. Color is pale straw and transparent, similar to macro-crap. Taste is slightly wheaty and very light. Very very light. When it’s hot and the 312 is cold, it’s quite refreshing. However, so is just about anything. I’d have to say, stick to the other Goose Island brews.
The color was light, pale golden.  The head was white, creamy, and laced some.  The aroma was wheat and sweet.  The flavor was strong wheat, but rotten somewhat.  The palate was very carbonated.
Different than what i was expecting. Very citrusy with a nice after taste. Overall is very refreshing and easy to drink. Goes well with a nice meal at a pub.

Bottled at Monk’s Café, Stockholm.  Cloudy yellow, airy head. Citric nose. Medium dry with light body and rounded mouthfeel. Streamlined but quenching, and with a pleasant citric twist. No bitterness. A good beer in a pointless style.

A unique wheat ale that is highly quaffable, delicious and not overly complex.  It is very crisp and refreshing.  Though lacking in any real hop presence, it is full of sweet malt with hints of corn and sweet potato, and delivers an appetizing semi-sweet bright finish.  312 seems to carry a somewhat German hefe-weizen influence, but is mainly American in style, and is one of Goose Island’s most popular draft beers.  It is a bright, hazy, sunny blonde ale with a bit of sediment and a huge, attractive, fluffy white head. There are doughy, breadlike malt and wheat aromas with fresh pineapple and cloves. Crisp and sharp on the palate, this urban wheat ale refreshes and stimulates, making it an obvious choice for summer evenings.

Golden pour with fizzy white head.  The aroma is...um, risking sounding like my wife..."it smells like beer".  The taste is mild wheat with refreshing citrus (orange and a touch of lemon) presence and tinges of floral.  This really improved as it warmed.  Light and refreshing.  The only complaint is that the wheat presence was light.  High carbonation, but this still goes down easy.  A very fine summer drinking beer.  I thought it was pretty good.

Sweet wheat aroma, color is a hazy wheat color (imagine...in a wheat beer!)  The flavor is only average, but it goes down exceptionally smooth.  The smooth palate is really the only thing that stands out about this.  This is pretty much an average wheat beer, there’s nothing that would make me buy this over any other wheat beer I have tasted.
little lemon on nose, appearence is nice and somewhat hazy, flavor is hopped up more than most hefes(seems to be a micro trend in wheats), but that is one of goose’s traits, good summer beer

Light golden yellow pouring with a 1 inch white head and exhibiting good carbonation. Aroma is lightly sour malt. Flavor is light sour wheat. Body is medium and carbonation medium and brief. Finish is a little doughy.
I got this on draft at Tractor’s in Jackson, MO.  It came a hazy yellow, with a fizzy white hesd and light lacing.Nose of wheat and citurs.  Mild mouthfeel. Flavor is bsnana and citrus.  Dry finish.

On tap at Gino’s East Pizza.
Pours a hazy wheat looking golden yellow. Lighter looking than most wheats though. Small foamy white head that goes away fast. Not a very strong aroma, but some wheat and lemon to it. Not too complex. Pretty wheaty taste with some citrus lemons and a little bit grainy. Overall, a bad example of what Goose Island is to me. I love this brewery, but this beer is just not that good. I understand and support the whole mass producing crappy beer thing to make money, but it doesnt make me feel any better about this beer.

Bottle. Pours hazy yellow with a foamy head.  You know you’re off to a bad start when a beer looks EXACTLY like your urine.  Sweet wheaty aroma with some floral and lemony notes.  Slightly sweet wheaty malt with a lemony flavor that borders on an annoying sourness.  Really bad acidic finish and weird metallic aftertaste.  Thin bodied.  I bought this with a misplaced reliance on the prestige of the G.I. brand.  Waste of money.
Pretty terrible.  Maybe I’m just not crazy about wheat ales, but this one sucked.  Sour and boring.

Pours a hazy white yellow with a two finger creamy white head. The nose is wheaty, some lemongrass, a little grainy. The flavor is thin and grainy, some lemongrass, one dimensional. Thin mouthfeel. Not too great.
Great summer beer!  Smooth with just the right bite at the end, more than a few is not a problem!
pours hazy yellow, frothy head.  citrus and wheat in the aroma.  mostly citrus and a touch of banana in the flavor.  a bit of a watery finish.  not a terrible beer, but not my style.

A fried brought this to a surprise party at our house.  Warn and muggy day fit this well.  More flavor than the standard beers that people bring over, a hint of citrus and spice, but not enough character to drink again.  Might be a nice step for someone into the WWoCB (wonderful world of craft beers).

Bottle.  This is very light.  Hazy yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is kind of plain just some very mild citrus.  Flavor isn’t bland but it is rather boring.  Smooth and drinkable but I doubt I’ll drink it again.

On tap in Chicago (many places). Pours a clear golden color with a medium white head. The aroma is tons of wheat. The taste was a strong wheat presence with some citrus, maybe even pineapple. Pretty good.

Had on tap. Pours light golden with white head. Aroma is wheat and some light spices. Flavor is light and bland with hints of wheat, spices and a touch of light fruit. Good beer for a nice hot day and that is about it.
Pours a light hazy gold. The aroma is wheat and maybe some spicy citrus. The taste is American wheat and really not much more.
Draught. A kind of light American wheat. Not much hefeweizen character. Refreshing, but boring.
Not too bad, would make a good summer beer. not very much to say about this one.
Pours a moderately hazy-yellow with minimal head.  Wheat and spices are weak.  Not even close to Oberon or Whitsun.  A disappointment from an otherwise fine brewery.

Little aroma with decent color, this American Wheat is a good ’gateway’ beer, owing to the popularity of Goose Island in the US.
Not a bad interpretation of the style...the only problem is, this style is just lacking compared to the German and Belgian Wheats it’s derived from.
Bottle Pours out a hazy yellow topped with a nice wite head. Aroma of citrus and some wheat. Tast I pick up wheat, citrus, malt, and some yeast. A so so wheat.
Pours gold with white head. Doesn&rsquo;t taste as &quot;wheatish&quot; as I anticipated.  Decent beer, sort of like a pilsner to me.

Pours golden yellow with a thick cloudy appearance and a small white head. The aroma is very citrusy, whearas the flavor is of wheat and yeast and hops. Not the best goose island, but very refreshing.

On tap at the Ginger Man.  Pours a cloudy golden yellow with a small white head.  This was served with a lemon, which obscured the aroma somewhat, I just got some light fruits and faint spices.  Flavor predominantly of wheat, light fruits, flour, pizza dough.  I found this quite tasty.  Perhaps this must be had super super fresh to be enjoyable.   Contrary to what the ratings of this beer suggest, I really liked this wheat ale.

Pours hazy pale lemon yellow with white head. Aroma of strong citrus, lemon and grapefruit. Flavor is a bland wheat with a smidgen of citrus and yeast. The flavor is dominated by carbonation. Reminds me too much of the typical American macro brew.
Eh.  It’s drinkable, fairly refreshing, but nothing to it really. A bit of wheat flavor but no real wheat or yeast character.

This was my firsting whack at a Goose Island product.  Hopefully the rest of their line will turn out to be better than this one.  Not a bad tasting beer but really no outstanding qualiities.  Pretty much an average wheat, definitely not worth the premium price you pay for it.

Missed this one. This has to be the most popular micro brew in chicago.  Its nice and refreshing on a summer day and better than any macro brews here. So why not. Pours cloudy hazy yellow some head, an unfiltered look. Smell is of spice and wheat. Taste is of a faint watered down citrus/malts/wheat/spices and lots and lots of water. Finish is lifeless. Overall an average wheat.

Hazy pale yellow with a slowly diminishing soapy white head. Aroma of wheat, citrus and perfumed malts.  Taste of wheat and corn in a thin and lifeless body that finishes astringent.  I think I’ll stick to rural wheat beers.
An aggressively average beer, pouring golden yellow into my chilled glass with a substantial white head. The flavor is a malty wheat blandness with the merest hint of a hoppy follow through.
Bottle:  This beer is exactly what you would expect.  Cloudy pour, aroma of corriander spice, flavor is crisp and light citrus, bready.  Crisp, pale, bready malt finish.  Best served VERY COLD.

Let’s see... Urban Wheat.  Maybe they meant Urban as in a college town.  This is a pong-able beer and that is not a good thing.  Cloudy golden pour.  Thick sudsy white head that doesn’t go away.  Tons of carbonation.  Bread-like near the end.  Bad news, overall.
Was not terribly impressed.  It’s a typical American beer that’s trying just slightly harder than Budweiser to have some kind of flavor.  Not bad but certainly average.
Thanks unclemike.  Pours a mountain dew like color and honestly I would rather have a mt dew.Aroma is decent.  flavor isn’t.

On Tap,  This is Goose Island worst excuse for a beer.  Extremely light color wheat ale.  Taste is non descript.  Very little flavor.  Quickly diminishing head.  This is NOT a good beer.  Goose Island has did a dis-service by making this.

Bottle.  Pours lightly hazy yellow, thin white head.  Aroma of light cloves, flowers and wheat.  Initial taste of wheat, then some fruit and finishes with some bread.  Crisp, light to medium body.  Good summer easy drinking brew.
On tap pours a somewhat hazy golden color with a thin white head.  Has some aroma that smells like a soft wheat beer.  Taste is nothing spectacular and is uninteresting.  Boring brew.
Draft. pours a non descript yellow. Wheaty floral & light hops in the nose. crisp & easy drinking wheat beer. Well balanced & decent summer beer
Bottle. Yellow hazy pour with lots of wheat in the nose, some spiciness and malt in the flavor but wheat is the domineering character here.  Nothing special.

Draft… DLD’08… Hazy, straw-colored ale with a mid-sized, creamy, white head. Good retention. Lots of citrus and pale grains in the aroma. Light to medium-bodied with a mildly creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Sweet (too sweet) with reserved citrus. Finishes sweet and grainy.
Average beer weak taste over all. still far better then a normal commercial American beer such as Bud or Miller. Golden in color decent balance, weak head that leaves early on.
A rather bland drink. It has a decent citrus aroma with not much left to the imagination. A clear tan/orange color with a light taste. A typical wheat ale with no "WOW". Probably won’t buy again.

Bottle pours a whiter shade of pale with a decent head that leaves some lace.  The aroma is light banana clove and some floral hops going on.  The flavor is pretty bland, with a clovy finish and some yeast flavor.  The palate is nice and refreshing.  Overall, meh.
Very flavorful taste, light golden color....a truely amazing beer that is just in time for the season
Its cloudy in appearance, and real good.  its a little fruity and i like it, of course i do wheat beers are my favorite.
One of my favorite Goose Island brews. Thick, golden body and a sweet, fruity aroma traditional of wheat beers. Great unfiltered blend that lingers.
Pretty bland generic beer, on tap at Buffalo Wild Wings. Not too bad easy to drink. Wouldn’t buy again
another great summertime brew. Pours a bright, but cloudy golden colour with a medium sized white head. Tastey, lively fruit, citrusy character and soft, creamy wheat flavors throughout this beer.

Poured a surprisingly clear pale gold color.  For all the chest beating they do in their description about how it’s "unfiltered, hazy & cloudy" it really wasn’t all that much so.  The aroma was mild citrus, over light barley and wheat.  Overall aroma was restrained, but not unpleasant.  The flavor was a nice blend of light citrus with some nice wheat and hops that provided a nice finish.  Decent mouthfeel.  Refreshing and easy to drink.  Not bad.

Draught at Cabooses, Geneva, Illinois. I think this may have been the only microbeer available at this train station bar. It was served way too cold and had barely any aroma. However, when faced with Budweiser and Miller Lite, this is miles ahead.

12oz bottle-pours a foamy/bubbly white head and hazy yellow color.  Aroma is sweet light malty/wheat/creamy/rich, some citrus.  Taste is sweet light malty/wheat/creamy/rich, some citrus-orange, some spices.  Light side of medium body, some complexness but easy drinking.  Good effervescence.  Thanks to decaturstevo for sharing.

Draught at Cabooses, Geneva, Illinois. This hazy pale yellow beer was preferable to the macro lagers available at this railway station bar, but it was served far too cold and not as flavourful as better wheat beers.

wheat beer ? with a bit of imagination yes :)
as thirst quencher this beer isn’t that bad. lacks body and complexity. still some work to do

While technically a wheat, its very clear, and is almost more lager than wheat. Wonderful cascade flavor. I’ve had it in both bottle, and draft, and the bottle is much better. The hop profile seems to get lost on tap.

Hazey golden pour with medium head.  Aroma is of wheat and maybe some honey.  Taste is the same but more dominant wheat with a hint of spice.  Smooth brew but nothing special.  Not really worth a purchase.

Had on draft. Poured a very pale hazy gold. Large foamy head. Aroma of watered down citrus. Taste was very light wheat and oranges. I was very disappointed in this beer. Extremly watered down for a GI beer. Blah...
Bottle: Very average and one of the worst Goose Island beers that I have had.  Pours yellow with a full head.  Aroma of wheat.  Not much flavor.
by far not my favorite from the goose, hazy yellow,bitter fruits taste i’d expect more here

Pours a pale yellow with minimal white head that dissapates rapidly.  Smells of hops and citrus.  Taste was mainly hop, but ther is a slight tang as well.  Decent beer, but I’ve had better wheats before.
Pours a slightly cloudy golden with thin head. Aroma and taste is sweet and malty. A little bready yeast. Bland and boring.
Bottle.  this is a decent wheat ale.  good summer beer. I would drink this again
Bright pale golden hue, slightly hazy.  Good nose, aroma of fresh cascade hops.  Decent summer beer, more blonde ale than wheat ale.
A tasting at Three Cellars Milwaukee.  Pretty carbonated, and on the lighter side. Not much character here.

Nice, but not as strongly flavored as I like a wheat beer to be. Thin light head that didn’t last long, fairly carbonated, light aroma of wheat, citrus, and yeast. Tastes of wheat and bananas, with a bit of hops and citrus. Not bad at all, but I’d like more what and hops bitterness.

Yellow and a bit hazy. A light wheat beer for the masses seems to be the goal of this beer. Flavor is light, a bit of grainy wheat, a hint of citrus. Body is light and fizzy. Not much depth here, just a "Wheat Light" kind of beer that macro drinkers can enjoy and feel good about.

Pours a clear lemon yellow with very light white head. Aroma is of overwhelming citrus and yeast. Flavor is Lemon and wheat but very light, to the point of watery. Not that impressive---definitely expected more from goose island.

Pours hazy light staw with a fine white head, very similar to the look of hoegaarden.  Wonderful aroma for a wheat, citrus, yeast and wheat...doughy.    This is definitely one of the most delicate American wheats.  Spring water like crispness.  Pretty sugary, subtle flavors, with a yeasty,  un-malted wheat finish.  A lemon might be just what this needs (which is always unfortunate to say...)
pours hazy yellow. creamy flavor and palate.  sweet and malty, would be great in the dead of summer.
Goose Island 312 is a cloudy, light amber color with a lighter body than a standard wheat ale. Low bitterness, a smooth finish and a nice citrus aftertaste make this a refreshing beer.

An almost gold pour with a white head and lace. Aroma of light citrus and hints of paper. Very light malt with a hint of a pleasant bitter finish. A bit thin bur overall pretty good carbonation. Very good refreshing drinker that has a good finishing bitter and is pretty solid all round.
Bottle poured a hazy gold color with a decent whitish head that doesn’t last long. Very mild aroma of citrus. Fruity ale flavor. Good sessional brew.

Pours hazy with slight head. Taste is refreshing and flavorful for a wheat ale. If you like wheat ales, this is definitely a good one.  This is better than blue moon, but I’m not a big fan of wheat ales in general.
Bottle. Had this only once after more than a few other brews, so the details are a little hazy. Very flavorful wheat beer though. One of the best of the style I have had.
Draft.  A light colored light flavored beer.  Slightly fruity in flavor.  Good easy drinking alternative to light beer.

Nice wheat ale. I was expecting a little more from this brewery but good nonetheless. Aroma was average. Could pick up some light yeast and wheat. Pour was beautiful. I love unfiltered wheat beers. A swirling hazy gold with a one finger white head. Taste was a little bland. Wheat and yeast with light malt but the flavor disappeared after the swallow. Great lawnmower beer.
It was a very light beer, and its body was very clear with a hint of a yellow tint.  Not my first pick.

Bottle.  Pours clearer than one expects, slightly hazy golden with decent white head that reduces quickly.  Aroma and taste are mild, wheat, citrus with bready, dry finish.  A little thin, and not one of the best Goose Island brews.  Still, makes a great session brew.

Bottle. Pours a straw semi-hazy color. White head with low retention and lacing. Aroma of wheat, mild citrus and watermelon. The taste is very similar with a dry finish. I’m a bit confused as this is supposed to be unfiltered but is actually quite bright. A very drinkable brew, almost session like.
Light wheat beer. Fairly hazy, slightly hoppy. Medium head disappears quickly.
Pretty weak overall with a watery taste.  Average palate with a wheat/citrus feel.  Head was virtually non-existent.

An average American wheat ale.  Watery tasting with an average palate.  I need to try this again as I’ve recently become more interested in wheat ales and some of the Goose Island I’ve had over the past 6 months has actually been pretty good.

On tap, poured into a iced glass, with 2 large lemons by a goofy blonde barmaid. Drank the 1st down, then asked for one in a non-chilled glass, no fruit.

2 finger head, fades fast. 

Aroma: not much. 

Taste: Disappoining. VERY light, some corn, some light citrus. Not much going on there. 

Easy to drink, I may try it again as the weather gets warm. Actually would rather have a Budweiser, than this.
Pours a straw color with a small, frothy head. Aromas are bready with some sour mash notes underneath. Flavor is about the same. Tastes the same as it smells.
decent wheat beer by Goose Island.  lemon flavor and bitter.  Semi-cloudy and kind of generic compared to other goose island beers.  not that impressed

Never been a fan of the style, they always taste amd smell like sweat to me.  Not too bad, and more than once it has been the best option at a 7-11 or dive bar.  Local pride is the main reason to drink this.  I prefer the barley when I am drinking lighter stuff.

Bottle.  Pours very light hazy yellow with a small white head.  Very pale color.  Aroma is that normal American Wheat aroma - wheat, grains, flour, a little bit of rice or something.  A tiny bit of tartness or citrus comes out in the aroma but not much.  Taste is very watery, smooth, a little grainy with a non-existant finish.  Very light beer here.  While this is not a category of beers I like very much this one does not stand out at all.
Pale straw with a short living, white foam.  Very bland, unappealing and boring.

12oz bottle: Pours a hazy yellow with a soft cap that fades quickly.  The nose is weak, some bubble gum esthers if you reallly try.  The body was about the same for me - a bit hoppy with a nice balance of vanilla and banana, but nothing spectacular.  Tastes like an American Wheat yeast strain and lower alcohol.  I could drink quite a few on a hot day, but the style just seems to be a Hefe-light kind of approach.

Sampled via 12-oz bottle at 10th Annual Ice Cold Beer Festival in Minocqua, Wisconsin. Pours a semi-clear pale light straw brew with a thick white head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of light mulit-grain malt, some yeast, and citrus zest. Taste is light to medium bodied, light carbonation with flavors of light multi-grain malt with wheat, yeast and a touch of citrus zest. Finish is semi-dry with a lemon zest aftertaste.

Bottle. Aroma of wheat and citrus. Slightly hazy golden color with a decent white head. Medium bodied with fizzy/creamy carbonation. Flavor is wheat with citrus. Flavor fades rapidly, and the finish is a little grain and a touch of citrus that persists.

10-11-07  bottle 
 
Hazy yellow golden in color with light short-lived head.  Big heavy wheat aroma - nice malt and hops mixture.  A bit watery overall and weak on the palate.  Overly light in flavor and palate for my liking.  Quite thin.  Taste is somewhat lemony.
12oz bottle.  Pours cloudy gold with a white fluffy head.  Clean, slightly fruity aroma.  Taste is very light.  Be good after cutting the grass in the summer.

12 oz bottle (thanks Tom)

Straw, hazy (with the yeast poured in), Small white head (3/5)

Lt Malty aroma, fruity, no hops (6/10)

Fruity flavor w/ some malt.  pretty thin flavor, with a clean finish (5/10)

Light body, med Carb(3/5)

Not bad, but not too exciting.  would be a good summer beer, provided you were just thirsty (12/20)

There is a lot of hype about this beer, since I’m next to the 312 area code, but there isn’t too much to back it up for me.  It is slightly too light, slightly too muddled, slightly complex and not much else.  I guess it has a pleasant taste and is easy to drink, in the summer that is.
Draft. Hazy pale yellow with a white head. Lemony citrus aromas. Wheat spiciness in the flavor with hints of lemons. A bit thinner than I expected.
Bottle. Hazy golden colour with a medium white head. Spicy aroma with faint notes of hops. Light spicy taste, little bitterness.

Pours a hazy yellow unfiltered mess. Poured a decent head that dissipates. Smells citrusy, hoppy, and doughy. Tastes alot like its smell. Decent hop character for a wheat beer, but I kept getting a bready/doughy finish. Maybe it was something else that feels familiar but I can’t put my finger on. A beer I used to drink alot, but generally pass over for the Honker’s now.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color with a medium frothy head.  The aroma is sweet light malt and some citrus.  The flavor is yeasty with light citrus, and light sweet malts.  A slight touch of bitterness.  A touch on the watery side.
From a bottle.  I thought this beer was a light wheat.  Goes down easy, well balanced.  Just a little sweat and with hints of lemon.

Draught at the brewpub, Clybourn location
Cloudy blond color. Aroma of sugar and lemon zest. Tastes more like a Lager than a wheat, breadish. The final is quite crispy. Refreshing.
I hate wheat beers.  This however is the best of it’s kind.  Refreshing.  Hints of lemon.

On tap at Clybourn on 6/20/07: Pours a clear bright golden with a thin covering of white head.  Aroma of sweet orange citrus and pale malted wheat along with some floral noble hops.  Body starts lightly sweet and wheaty with a dull bitter balance.  Nothing that great, but pretty well done and drinkable for the style.

Draft (some sushi place in Chicago) – Gold with a thin white head.  Bland aromas of lemon, citrus, and hints of bread.  Light bitter flavors turn lemony and a touch yeasty.  Light bodied and thin, soft carbonation, soft citric finish.  Fine for sushi I guess, but really not a typical GI brew…

On tap.  Cloudy yellow with a bit of head.  Citrus,  grass,  and a stale foot smell.  The taste is the same but exchange a pissy alley with the foot.  Not horrible but something is completely off.  Why does it give me that feeling that I’m licking a dirty street corner every other sip?  Probably the worst goose beer I’ve tried,  but even that is a step up from most beers on tap at my local bar.
Bottle sampled. Pours a cloudy yellow with a small off-white head. Aroma of wheat, light citrus, and some lemon. Flavor is thin and mild with wheat, grass, light hops, and some citrus notes
Tap: Cloudy pale yellow color with a mild yeast & banana aroma.  Flavors of sweet corn and soap.  Definitely not my favorite brew.

I usually prefer something darker than a wheat ale, but this was really good. It’s mild with a solid bite of wheat malts. The honey and citrus tones are subtle but still nice, although I would’ve liked them to be a little stronger. Still, not a bad beer, although I’d rather drink two or three of them cold after mowing the yard than sip with a couple of beer geeks.

Honey yellow color with no head. Aroma is wheaty with a bit of hops and lemon. Mouthfeel is very creamy, much more so than I anticipated. Semi-spicy wheat flavors abound. Solid but unspectular ale from a great brewery.

I’ve had this beer many times on tap and bottled - Most recently from a 12 oz into a shaker.  Pours a straw yellow with lots of haze and cloudiness.  Nice head if you pour straight in.  Looks OK.  Aroma is very mild - slight wheat, slight citrus, a little earthy/grassy.  Smells decent, but a bit light.  Taste is very light (read: watery and slightly dissapointing), light citrus/lemon, slight wheat and thats about it.  Overall, it’s very light and unforunately only 4.2%, but it is nice and refreshing on a hot summer day.  You can do better, but it’s OK.

Pours a sickly pale, cloudy yellow in a Weizen.  Smell is obvious of wheat and big on a light citrusy lemon smell as well and is overall quite nice.  Taste is wheaty, somewhat tart and lemony, and I can swear I taste the alcohol in this 4.2% beer though...  Very thin, watery, and somehow tastes a bit boozy.  I actually like wheats, but this wasn’t worth revisiting.

On tap, and served in a shaker.  This beer poured a lightly hazed golden color with a one-finger thick, off-white head that quickly faded away to nothing.  Some very faint lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of wheat malt, very mild citrus notes, and also some grassy/hay notes.  The flavor was crisp and light, displaying notes of wheat, lemon, and also some faint orange.  The mouthfeel was refreshing and light-bodied with a solid dose of carbonation.  I guess this would be fine to session outside on a hot day, but it is definately not one of my favorites.
from a 12 oz. bottle., pours slighly cloudy, but nothing like a hefe.  tastes of grass, not pleasant at all.  try paulaner hefe or ayinger brau wiesse if you want the real deal.

12oz bottle - Poured a hazy light straw color with nice white head. Aroma was sweet and smelled like grains. A light mouthfeel with wheat and malt taste. This beer is very easy to drink and is slightly watered down tasting which is nice on a summer day. I was fairly satisfied because it is alot better than Miller or Bud at close to the same price $6.29 a 6pac.
Very cloudy - too cloudy.  Too yeasty - covered up the wheat flavor.  A little spice and citrus.
Sampled countless times at Goose Island, yellow color, white head. Fairly simple and straightforward. Mildly tart finish, the body and finish dont work for me.
Clear, yellow with a white head.  I thought this was a pretty decent brew.  It would hit the spot on a hot day.

12oz bottle. light lemony yellow color has a slight haze. bright white frothy head. yeasty citric aroma smells clean. toasty grains play a part as well as mild bubblegum. a soft grainy easy drinking wheat ale. some fruit bubblegum and dry crusty finish are also present.

Bottle at Mcguilicuddy’s. Pour was brilliantly clear golden yellow with lots of carbonation to display. Head and lacing not that impressive, as this style normally has more to offer. Aroma was herbal and fruity. Flavor was earthy, herbal, and fruity, yet no wheat bite and not nearly enough hops in the finish for an Am Wheat. Light body. Came across as a wheat-based blonde ale with little character, only decent drinkability.
bought as part of a variety pack.  poured slightly hazy gold, minimal head.  aroma is light, sweet while taste was citrus and yeast.  nothing special.
33 cl bottle, Fargo. Hazy golden colour, musty lemon aroma, both transfer to the flavor, quite citrusy, interesting but not my favorite.
For a beer that claims to be so meticulously brewed, including being unfiltered, this is quite pedestrian.
I usually like goose island but this is not my favorite by far.  yellow with a kinda sweet smell and a yeasty taste.

Date: 06/20/2007

Mode: Draft

Source: Brewpub, Clybourne



hazy yellow, fine white head, drippy lace, 
sweet wort aroma, 
light sweet malt flavor, lots of bready yeast character give the impression of unfermented wort flavor, light bitterness



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20

Rating: 2.9/5.0
Drinkability: 7/10

Score: **/4

This is a really poor offering from Goose Island. Pours to a hazy lemony yellow with a thin white head that dissipates quickly and leaves little lacing.  Aroma is stale wet straw and the mouthfeel is bland. Flavor is more of the wet straw and grass, with no wheat, spice or dough to be found. Not surprisingly, the finish leaves a bad stale taste.

Stay away from this one!!

Pours a crisp blonde with a medium white head and fine particulate.  Aroma is wheat with mild citrus fruits.  Taste is carbonated and up front with mild banana and citrus flavors.  Finishes with a nice wheat taste.  An easy drinking summer wheat.
Can I have another?  Might need a wee bit more hops, but still an outstanding brew.  Liked it nearly as well as Bell’sOberon.
The aroma and flavor of this american wheat beer is not too shabby. More wheat aroma and fllavor than most--overall a great summer ale.
Cloudy orange body with a medium creamy off-white head. Sweet caramel flavor with a hint of banana. Sweet wheat flavor with a light caramel ending.

Odd label on this 12 oz brown bottle. Pour is hazy like a wheat but not real cloudy. Lighter yellow vanilla color comparable to many american wheats. Slightly tart and somewhat spicy. Less carbonation than I like in a wheat, usually you think of wheats as being more of a smooth champagne tingle. It’s probably because it’s urban and not rural. Look out, I am torrified buy the wheat. OK for a wheat and as expected compared to other american wheats. Cannot hold a candle to Marzoni’s 22 or 	Harpoon UFO Hefeweizen.  On par with Hopsun and Witsun.  Better than JW dundee’s american wheat version.
Pale with white thin head.  Light wheat flavor.  A wheat beer for the ’Miller Light’ crowd.

on tap at the Elephant & Castle, chicago.  pale light yellow color, not too cloudy.  tall, thin foamy white head that goes quickly.  aroma is grassy and faint wheat malt, more like a light lager.  flavor is mostly the same, grassy and light wheat malt.
Robe blonde légèrement voilée surmontée d’une mousse blanche mince. Arômes de céréales. Saveurs de malt, de céréales et de houblon aromatique.

An old standard in the Chicago area, this unobtrusive American wheat is a solid performer, but without too many bells and whistles. Easy drinking with a balanced profile, 312 pours a cloudy maize and sports a medium sized, quickly dissipating white head. Lacing is minute. The nose shows a bit of honey and hops, and the body is drying, with a lite citrusy finish. A good wheat beer for non-wheat beer drinkers.

Pours a cloudy, golden color with a white head.  Not very much on the nose.  Aroma is of wheat, citrus, lemon, and some spices.  Flavor is a little stronger then the nose but it dies pretty quickly without much of a lingering flavor.  Flavor is mostly wheat and a little bit of citrus.  Not the best american wheat I’ve ever had.

Chalky unimpressive wheat.  Small indications of must on the nose and very dry, too dry, palate on this beer make it nearly unenjoyable.  Goose Island makes good beer -- but this is not one of them -- bland.
Matte gold color, flowery and citrus aroma.  Bready, citrus, and mild flavor.  Pleasant.

Pours a slightly hazy yellow golden color with a medium white head.  weak aroma of wheat, lemon and doughbread.  Taste is wheaty with a small lemon punch to it and a slightly sweet finish.  Bland and not much of anything here.
Pale, cloudy golden with disappearing head /  Bread and lemon nose / Light body / Crisp lemon and bread flavors with clean finish / A  decent light beer.

Very light golden-yellow in color. Very light carbonation. Next to no head. Nothing to stick to the sides just a very light ring. Wheaty smell with very light hops. Citurs aroma just seems to fit a nice hot day. Tastes wheaty but watery. Not quiet what I expected. Almost like it’s missing something. The citrus and wheat satisfies but still a bit thin for my taste. Very clean and lightly carbonated which is very refreshing but still to thin. Very watery and thin. Not enough to make it a regular purchase. But this beer sure does satisfy on a hot day! Very clean and lightly carbonated which is very refreshing but still to thin. This is an easy drinking beer for a nice hot summer day. Easily drink these with your friends at a barbecue or at the beach. Good flavors, Good aromas and just light enough. You can drink these but I still think it needs more body.

Very faint wheat aroma comes from this beer.  It pours a pale, cloudy yellow, with a moderate white head.  Almost no flavor at all, just hints of wheat and a touch of orange.  It’s not a bad beer, but there’s not much here.  This may be a good gateway beer.
Hazy yellow body with massive white head.  Wheat and some faint herb on the nose.  Cereal grain taste with a yeast bite on the finish.

On tap in Chicago.  Pours yellow hazy with little lacing on glass.  Smells of mild sweet fruits (maybe citrus) but not overwhelming.  Taste was mild, fruity, light hops, light on the carbonation.  Easy beer for summer drinking.  Not very complex, but I enjoyed it.

Poured a hazy yellow with about a finger worth of head, no retention.  Aromas of sweet grass, light malt.  Tasted of apricot and other fruits, maybe a little honey.  Aftertaste was clean.  I don’t know if they are trying to make this their signature beer, that is widely accessible for the lite beer drinking crowd, but it was nothing special and very forgettable, not very representative of the style either
pours clear golden color, well carbonated. not much taste, some sweet yeastiness, cirtus, mild hop finish. easy to drink, but boring.

This was a great beer. Had it on tap, actually, had about 3 of them on tap :) . The taste of this beer was very new to goose island standards, pale, not as harsh as the other GI flavors. went down smooth with a nutty and fruity taste, the aftertaste was actually really good! Best part- its from chicago!!

This was listed as a hefeweizen at the bar, but it didn’t have the full knack of a hefe. It does have a good bit of phenolics in it, like a witbier without the spicing. Big wheat character, though. Light and spritzy. Not bad.
One of my new favorite wheat ales. The hint of citrus flavor was a welcomed surprise.
Too clear for my tastes. Crisp and slight citris flavor if you try. Best served cold on a hot day since flavor doesn’t get better as beer gets warmer.

Light golden clear color with no appreciable head.  Aromas of very sweet malt, banana, and bubblegum??.  The taste, as noted by others, is nearly nonexistent...  There are flavors of citrus, light sweet malt, and perhaps a touch of hops.  This is far too light on the palate - It is more like drinking carbonated water than beer.  Not my favorite.

Draft.  Light color.  Little head.  Tastes watered down.  Not like any other goose island beer because it is maybe the most boring.  Tastes watered down.  I would skip this one but it is not too expensive.
Golden and hazy with little head.  Aroma of hops.  Has the flavor of hops but not much of it.  Very little flavor.

Pours a light yellow with tiny particles in suspension and a small, frothy, off-white head that diminishes. This one is pretty clear for a wheat. The nose is sweet wheat malt and yeastiness. The mouthfeel is light and thin with a clean, smooth finish. Sweeter than most American wheats that I have tried, the flavor is light honey and wheat with a faint citrus in the the finish. A decent American wheat, and one that I wouldn’t mind seeing at a family BBQ.

Massive head, and a bold yellow appearance. Wonderful aroma, almost apricot-like, very much wheat. I’m a little underwhelmed by the flavor, but it’s still good; it’s a wheat beer that’s smooth, for the most part. Perhaps I poured it improperly resulting in the large head that made it a little difficult to drink. Either way, I will very likely try this beer again sometime, and I’d recommend it to others too!

On tap. Nose was slightly of citrus. Not much going on. Unfortunately, this carried over to the taste. Very watery mouthfeel. I was surprised this beer was made by Goose Island. Almost a sad attempt by a micro brew at something that would appeal to the mainstream pale lager taste....but not be a pale lager. Shame on Goose Island and shame on this beer. Not worth drinking again!
On tap at old Chicago in rockford.  No head to speak of.  cloudy,yes and drinkable.  Strong lemon taste.   Summer sunset is a more balancrd brew.
Chicago trip. Monday 14:17+. On tap at Clybourn. Hint of haze. Pale yellow. Hint of chemical in the nose. Creamy plain taste. Muddled wet grain. Not joyful.

On draught. Yellow-gold translucent with frothy, white head--really a nice hat for an American wheat. Some wet sourdough aroma, wheaty-yeasty flavor with some lemon-zest notes. A bit wet. Refreshing and sessionable wheat beer that does have some character.

Rated 8/8/06:  Not much doing with this beer, no bad aspects but nothing spectacular either. Aroma is a mellow wheat with an ever so slight citrus scent. Nice appearance, hazy golden yellow with a good white head, very crisp. Mouthfeel is full and clean. Flavor is basically standard for an American Wheat. It is enjoyable but I really wanted more out of this beer.
yellow pour, clear with minimal head...aroma of grain, light grass, and a touch of citrus...flavor is mostly earthy with small citrus complements... somewhat spicy as well..

Bottle from Ryan.  Thanks.  Ive wanted to try this one for a while, and I finally got my chance.  Kind of disappointing really - just tastes like what I think something that is in a bottle that says BEER should taste like.  Some corn flavors, grain tasting, smooth and light though.  Not bad, but its no oberon.  Thanks man.

Cloudy, light yellow pour. Grainy, grassy, slightly spicy aroma. Flavor has a tangy finish, only slightly sweet at the start. Thin body, but clean, crisp mouthfeel. Not much else. Easy drinking, thirst quenching.

Aroma is light citrus and hay.  Color is cloudy pale yellow with a white diminishing head.  Flavor is mild, light citrus qualities with a bitter grassy aftertaste.  Light bubbly mouth-feel. Ok overall.
Thin, gold, small white head. Very light aroma and mouthfeel. I prefer a Belgian Wit to an American Wheat style, but this is drinkable in a pinch.
Bottle. Pours a hazy straw gold with a thin white head.  Light  grassy aroma.  Very light mouthfeel, definite american wheat flavor.  Might make a good hot weather beer.
moderately hazy, thin white head. aroma is of yeast, lemon, and grass. flavor is lightly earthy, very lemony. not too bad. typical american wheat.

Gift from Brigadier, thanks!  Aroma of subtle banana, lemon, very subtle cherry or other red, berry-like fruit.  Pale yellow, with a touch of cloudiness and a thin, white head.  Light flavors of lemon and banana and a quick finish with a touch of graininess.  Light palate, slightly watery.  Quick drinking beer without major flaws.
Draft.  Hazy yellow with a big white head.  Lots of carbonation.  Spicy aroma with lots of citrisy flavor. Fizzy. Not that bad.
It looks a bit cloudy. I don’t smell much of the aroma. It tastes spicy, with a bit of the bitterness but has a sweet after taste.

This was not one of those dry or bitter wheat ales.  This beer was really smooth with a bit of lemon flavor. It has nothing particularly special about it, but it is consistent.  I must disagree with others and say that I enjoyed this brew.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Sour wheat, lemon, light malt.  Boring.  Appearance:  Light orange in color and hazy.  White head was full and foamy with decent retention.  Not much lacing.  Flavor:  Lightly sour wheat, some light malt and yeast, lemon.  Spritzy finish.  Palate:  Medium-light bodied and a little watery.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  Dull and boring.  Nothing that would make me want to order another.
I love this stuff! One of my favorite wheat beers. It’s got a lemony wheaty thing going on.....light, crisp and refreshing. Not much complexity, but very flavorful...it really hits the spot.
Bottle.  Hazy yellow body.  Smells of wheat.  Flavor was wheat and sweet, not much complexity.  Felt fine in the mouth.  Nothing exceptional but could be okay for summer.

Pint - Aroma of wheat, malt and a touch of hops.  Pours hazy gold with a medium head and good lacing.  Flavor is a boring match to aroma.  Palate is thin.  I suppose if I was eating hot wings this might be a good beer.  Left to it’s own devices, it’s pretty boring.
Doughy, lemony aroma.  Slightly cloudy, gold, frothy thin head.  Moderate hops, a bit cereal.  Medium to medium light mouth. Somewhat buttery.

I always expect Goose Island beers to be better than they are, and I am always disappointed.  I got a pint of this at Prarie Moon in Evanston and tossed half of it.  Beer is a pale yellow with a small head, only slightly hazy.  Nose of lemon and sour malt.  Taste of lemon, none of the complexity often present in a wheat beer.  Mostly pretty boring, probably fine after mowing the lawn or something.  Average for a wheat, at best.
Not a bad beer, very light and refreshing, nothing extraordinary about it though.  Some friends highly recommended it, but I think their recommendation was a bit over-rated.

12oz. bottle.  Lightly grainy and sweet aroma, full of wheat malt character and doughy, bready yeast with a touch of lemon citrus and honey.  Pale, cloudy, yellow color with a very slight head and few swirls of sediment, no lacing to speak of.  Flavor profile is lightly bitter, tart and quenching, some malt showing through but the gentle sweetness that accompanies it only really becoming apparent towards the finish, and even then combined with the lingering citric sharpness.  Ample effervescence on the palate, paired with a light, somewhat watery body.  Perhaps nothing spectacular, but certainly inoffensive and seems to fit the bill of a warm-weather quencher fairly well as the sweetness in the flavor is minimized.  Better than some examples of this style I’ve tried.
I put this side by side with the summertime ale.  More substance, visible upon the pour and on the nose.  I am not a wheat fan, but I find this brew pleasant and a good representative of the style.

Pours a hazy, typical AW, nothing special, decent head.  Aroma is mostly cascades, unusual for this style, and in my opinion, a big improvement to the style.  Flaor is similarly familiar with a twist.  Ultimately , this comes across as an APA made with wheat rather than barley, which puts it well ahead of most in this usually flavorless style.

4/1/07: Bottle. 
 Xtra pale, hazy, lemon body with a white rim of carbonation.  Hoppy, tea-like nose with hints of lemon.  Flavor is similar to drinking an iced tea.  Would be very refreshing for a hot summer day.  Bring on the 90° temps!  Crisp finish.
Very weak aroma, hazy dark yellow with a very small head.  The appearance is not cloudy enough for a wheat ale in my opinion, and the body and finish are weak.

Draft Paulie’s Bar and Grille-A cloudy orange with no head. Aroma of orange and it had a taste of orange and a bit of coriander. Another typical American Wheat. I was expecting more from Goose on this one.

Nice beer, very drinkable.  Was a little too clear for a wheat beer, would have preferred more cloudiness.  Also, and maybe because of the clarity, the color was a bit off.  A little more orange and less yellow would be preferable.  Very drinkable, and much more enjoyable than domestic light beers, regardless of what anybody says in these posts.  Seems this beer is an answer to Bell’s Oberon and/or Winter Wheat.  From what I understand, Bell’s doesn’t allow (or restricts...and maybe this has all changed since I read the article) distribution into Chicago because the distributors there tend to corrupt the beer.  Not a place for a plug for Bells I admit, but I respect the brewers at Bells for caring about the quality of their beer all the way to the consumer.  This beer, different enough from the Bells offerings, gives the good people of Chicago a nice alternative.

I think I strained a nostral trying to pull some aroma off this beer.  What element of fragrance it does possess is like that of a stale and flavorless orange.  If one were to match the flavor you merely need to mix 2 parts Sunny-D with 1 part carbonated water.  The palate is sticky and stale.  There is an aftertaste similar to that which one would receive from eating a pound of the off-white portion of an orange rind.  If I owned a goose, I would rub its nose (or bill) in this beer while saying "come on, Goose, you’re better than this".

On tap at Gino’s.  Flavor was crisp and somewhat refreshing, but not complex or very flavorful at all.  Flavor and aroma were heavy on the wheat; in fact thats all I really tasted.  Did not pick up on any hops or spice.  Body was not very creamy.  Just ok, but not bad
Draft.  Very wheaty smell, same with the taste.  Not much other flavor.  Kind of tastes like miller high life.  Cascade hops were unnoticable.
Good pour, smooth taste. A decent wheat, but unimpressive. Probably the best widely available, but the taste seems to have mellowed now that Goose Island is giving it wider distribution.

Had this one on tap at Old Chicago with a calzone. Appearance was pale yellow with a medium white head. Aroma was of citrus and orange peel. The taste was tangy and grassy with notes of citrus and lemon. Watery mouthfeel. Taste seemed to fade away quickly and with food faded away completely. An OK light wheat for summer, but there are probably better ones out there.
I,ve never been a big fan of wheat beer but thought this one might suprise me ,seeing as how i like most of the Goose island lineup.   But this is one Goose island product that i can not reccomend .

Poured from a 12oz bottle, the color is golen wheat. Very cloudy, but in this brew the haziness enhances the color. Sweet aromas on this one. Lemongrass, apples, pears, with some maltiness. This beer is pretty thin and light bodied. While the mouth is fairly creamy, the finish is somewhat soft and weak.

It really isn’t as bad as some make it out to be.  It’s just a little less than what one would expect from Goose Island.  Tasted orange and lemon fruitiness with not much on typical beer flavors (malt or yeast).  But it’s still one I will be drinking again.
After a second try this is way to watery with almost no character. The tap version is slightly better but not by much. Its easy to drink but pours a pale yellow color with no head. Not good.

Tap @ Bandera in Chicago, very clear (unfiltered?), pale yellow, no lacing.  Minor aroma and even less on the taste, high in carbonation.  Some sort of earthy aftertaste; general not appealing and very disappointing for GI...

12 oz bottle

Goose Island generally makes solid beers but this is very disappointing.  It is not a terrible beer but once again the first word that came to mind after I was done was ’mediocre’.  While it is totally inoffensive that means all potential for enjoyment has been sucked out of it.  This is a beer that you could hand to a non-beer geek friend, let him drink out the bottle and they would probably enjoy it.  On the other hand, if you are looking for a standout beer check elsewhere.
Aroma / Appearance - An opaque golden body sits in the glass with a disappointingly minimal amount of carbonation.  Muted grains, a faint yeastiness and dull malt profile form a very safe nose that goes out of its way to not offend even the weakest of noses.  It is bland and offensive which is perhaps giving it a little more credit than it deserves.
Flavor / Palate - Wheat, rye and honeycomb cereal create an ephemeral sensation on the tongue that washes away in seconds.  A faintly bitter finish like the dregs of a package of Fischers nuts is all that remains.  If you focus it is possible to detect lemon juice and orange rinds.  In fact, it reminds more of an orange-based degreaser than anything that someone should drink/eat.  Goose Island has a beer for the masses here which is not to say that it is bad but that you should not have any expectations.
Just a pretty standard american wheat style here. Nothing special about it. It’s got just a slight wheat flavor, and good bite.
not a big fan of wheat beers. pours golden with white head. hazy color, slight floral and lemony-fruit (as opposed to lemony hop) smells. smooth body and a slightly dry finish. ok but nothing special

Bottle.  Lots of wheat and yeast in a malty nose, lemon and grain with some piney orange Cascade (the mystery ingredient!).  Particulate pale yellow with lots of carbonation and a sticky white head.  Lots of citrus up front with some acidity to match the doughy, bready malt.    Light cascade presence.  Some wheat in the finish but not really dry.  Not sure what to make of this one, doesn’t really conform to a rigid style and, despite the carbonation and light body, isn’t really refreshing.  On the whole, crafted but dull.
Pours orange-yellow. Thin wheat flavor with very little body. Refreshing in a sense that it wouldn’t be bad on a summer day, but it isn’t horribly satisfying.
Not very imressive, had on draft in Chi. IL. Off yellow color, overly carbonated one of the worst Goose Island has to offer

sure doesn’t match that fab description. thin watery, shallow, fizzy. a slight haze, but no indication of yeast. It’s a good thing it’s not like any other goose brews. and it was less than I expected. This was a sample.

12oz, pours very clear piss yellow with no head. nose is very yeasty and coriander. taste is yeasty, vegatable, lemony, pepper, with mild citrus. mouthfeel is fizzy. flavors are blended pretty well and this is refreshing.

Bottle.  Pours cloudy-clear yellow with lively carbonation.  Hoppy and grassy on the nose.  Tastes of flat grass with faint lemon and green vegetables thrown in a blender and pureed.  Watery mouthfeel, but not too watery.  Average at best.
draft.  clear golden with thin white head, the aroma is weak citrus.  rather undistinguished wheat profile.

Bottle.  Poured cloudy straw color.  Some foam that hung around for about 5 minutes.  Aroma is distant citrus, bit of malt.  The taste is muted wheat and bubbles.  Surprised at the carbonation.  Nothing really stands out in this one, and certainly is not a big wheat, but it is quite drinakable.

First time I’ve been disappointed with a GI product. Poured a cloudy blonde with a healthy head. The aroma was foul, but there wasn’t much of it so I’ll give them some points there. Flavor was sweet with bananas and a little malt. Just not much there.

Pours a hazy yellow, topped by a fizzy quarter inch of nearly white foam. Good carbonation is evident. No head retention, no lacing. Slight dry wheat aroma. 

Slight wheat flavor - dry but not really tangy. More of a cereal grain than anything else. Light body. Generic hops for balance - no character. You know - that’s it - the lack of character in this beer. It is decent, it is well made, but it does nothing for me.

Hazy pale yellow body, like a lemonade but with straw tones, thin off-white head. Earthy, biscuity aroma. Light, tart, bready body, grassy. Tastes a bit stale despite the 10 April 2007 drink by date, although, come to think of it, that same taste characterizes their Summer Ale. Rather dull and boring, and I’m not a big fan of the palate, either. Pass.

From my tasting notes at an "earlier" date.  On tap @ Old Chicago.  Poured a slightly hazy straw golden with a small creamy white head.  Aroma of some cardboard/paper, light lemons, tinge of banana.  Flavor is the same with a lot of citrus and tang coming through.  Watery body and highly carbonated.  Meh.

Faint aroma, small disappearing head, and little carbonation. Bright golden color. Last few drops added cloudiness that slowly sank to the bottom of glass. Okay flavor, somewhat citrus- but not much to it.

312 is a typical American Wheat beer. It has a nice crisp taste that I enjoy on a hot summer day. A little bit of citrus and banana taste, but not something that you would notice over the wheat unless you drank a lot of it and paid attention.

If I want a 12 pack of beer that is pretty good and not too pricey, I’ll pick up 312. Aside from that, it’s probably not something that I’d casually drink.
Dark yellow with a bright white head.  Mild, yeasty aroma.  Lightly flavored, in a typical American Wheat way.  Highly carbonated.  Good with a lemon slice.

Funny thing happened as I drank this one.  The more I drank the more of a bitter aftertaste I had in my mouth.  Never saw the cloudy appearance associated with unfiltered wheat ales, and I saw the gal pull it directly into the glass and set it in front of me.  I found this to be average, something I wouldn’t turn down, but wouldn’t go out of my way to get one.

Very light straw color, is cloudy and has a small amount of white head for a wheat beer.  Some spice in the aroma, with lots of banana.  The aroma was lacking in strength, however.  The flavor lack a lot.  Some banana in the finish.  Some tartness.  This resembles a pale lager way to much to me.  The lemon actually seemed to help this beer... ouch...
Pours hazy golden with light white head.  Faint citrus aroma, but not much else.  Flavor is smooth but lacking.

Not a lot of aroma but what there is seems to be mostly cloves.  This beer is advertised as unfiltered but is much more clear than other unfiltered offerings.  Mouthfeel is somewhat syrupy but it is quite dry in taste.  There is a hint of banana but also some soap that gives an unpleasant bite.  Perhaps just a hint of sweet citrus is evident, but not very much.  Some lemon can also be found.  I love wheat beers but was disappointed by this one.  It comes from a great brewer, too which adds to the disappointment.

(Tap) Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small amount of white head. Smooth flavor, with mild citrus notes and a little bit of wheat mixed in. Light in mouthfeel and charactor. Overall, not a bad beer, but not as good as I expected.

Nice deep golden color.  Nose of cookies and grain.  Light citrus.  Moderate dough and soap.  Very light hints of banana and honey.  Not bad but not good.  Decent wheat beer but I think Boulevard does it better.
Starts nicely if you let it sit for about 3 seconds, but I agree that it feels somewhat lacking in body as if it were watered-down.

Pours a bright white cloudy head with a characteristic wheat body.  Aroma is somewhat odd...not necessarily pleasant, but not really bad either.  Nice on the palate with a nice, smooth finish, but the flavor is somewhat lacking, with an empty feel to the brew.  A light fruity flavor, particularly lemony,  is evident, but overall, this beer was hollow and lacked any distinguishable trait...somewhat of a disappointment

Bottle at Pier 32 in Hamilton, IN. Marked best when consumed by 022107. Poured a very small off-white head that quickly dissipated, sparse lacing, visible carbonation, slightly cloudy, and a yellow hue. Nose was sweet, wheat, spicy, hops, fruity, and crisp. Flavor was sweet, thin, wheat, spicy, some maltiness, and a little bit fruity. Fairly smooth mouthfeel and a bit thin. Light body. A so-so brew.

How about 411, have you seen a flavorful wheat beer?  Not here.  I suppose the "urban" quality just ran over any of the farmhouse feel to this style but this was just aweful.  Never been a fan of GI but this was just bad.

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy pale golden color.   Smallish white head that settles.   Aroma is wheat, lemon, straw, floral.   Taste is lemon, wheat, spice, floral.   Palate is light with decent carbonation.   Mediocre.

This was on-tap at the last hotel I stayed at when visiting Chicago.

Appearance was an odd semi-transparent appearance.  It was only a bit cloudy and still transparent.  Usually, it seems beer commits to either being cloudy or clear and sparkling.  This one seems to straddle that line, which is not extremely endearing.

The beer came with an orange garnish, which seemed to dissipate the head.

Odor was mild and slightly sweet, possibly due to the orange slice.

I discarded the orange garnish, but the beer still tasted sweet with an artificial citrus sweetness reminsicent of Blue Moon Belgian White Ale.  It seemed almost like the orange slice was meant to explain this chemical artificiality, although my orange slice never got close to my beer.  Other than this unpleasant citrus astringency, the beer was OK.

I don’t plan on having this again.  Honker’s Ale and the Christmas beer from Goose Island are much, much better.

Draught from The Pub poured into shaker with a lemon garnish - Pours clear gold with a very minimal head; Lemon and wheat to the nose; Lemon, wheat and a hint of pine hops on the initial taste; A bland wheat backtaste;  Medium watery palate; Too much carbonation; Not impressed. Goose Island is normally spot on with their brews, but this one leaves a good bit to be desired. Lots of the lemon probably came from the garnish.
Hazy in appearance.  Not much of a head at all.  A little light for a wheat.  Easy drinking, though, with hints of banannas and mild spices.

Nice, but not as strongly flavored as I like a wheat beer to be. Thin light head that didn’t last long, fairly carbonated, light aroma of wheat, citrus, and yeast. Tastes of wheat and bananas, with a bit of hops and citrus. Not bad at all, but I’d like more what and hops bitterness.

Bottle. Hazy very effervescent yellow body with a lasting thin head. Nose-very dusty and “old” smelling. Taste-dusty, moldy, wheaty, medium-high CO2, light orange, slightly vegetal like celery or lettuce. A very unoffending wheat beer that is easy to drink. I would drink more of this if I could.
Doesn’t give as much as some would like, but it doesn’t ask for much either.  Acid crisp cuts your tongue like a Chicagoan wind-rip.   Man with trash-stache recommended highly.

12oz bottle in pint glass. Decent brew.  An american wheat, id prefer a sunset wheat to this.  Very small and fizzy head that dissipated very very quickly.   Average mouthfeel, a little sweet.  Id drink it again.

Thin white head of fine bubbles.  Good carbonation.  Lots of floaters.  Not really wheat floaters though.  More like chunky floaters.  Light vegetal aroma with a little lemon and weak hops.  Color is a medium gold.  Flavor is plesant but a little weak.  Some wheat and a little biscuit malt.  Finish is a little grainy but clean.  A decent wheat brew but nothing special.
a surprisingly bad beer from a great brewery.  This is a one note wheat that’s very forgettable.  Save your cash and get something else folks!

On draught at Barleys in Overland Park, Kansas. Pours a dense gold with a white head and lace. Light-bodied with a medium mouthfeel where a very light pale ale flavor tried to peek out beyond the wheat. Surprisingly clean, with a subtle hops crispness in the aftertaste. An interesting Wheat.
A cloudy, golden yellow with just a little bit of carbonation. Head fizzled out quickly. Nice and bready and goes down smooth. Fairly decent American wheat beer.
ok wheat beer still no where close the best ive had but ok nice color tastes good farily smooth nice aftertaste overall an ok try at wheat nice job

Pours orange/yellow with a white head.  It has a very faint wheat nose.  The flavor was a little more noticeable but still light, wheat and bananas were picked up.  It goes down smooth and overall was very drinkable.
not to bad for an american wheat beer.medium yellow body descent size off white head. aroma is not an overpowering wheat scent.would not drink more than six though or a killer hangover will get you!

Medium yellow, nice head.  Aroma of wheat, quite bready.  Rough mouthfeel from the carbonation.  Flavor is a straightforward American Wheat.  Perhaps the faintest hint of hops at the end, but not much going on there at all.  Not bad, but not great.  Glad to try it though.  Thanks Secret Santa!

sampled at columbus alefest.  pours hazy yellow with a small head.  little to no aroma with just a hint of fruityness.  wheat flavor, subtle spiceness and little hoppyness.  overall, a bland wheat, but would be refreshing on a hot day.

Bottle into shaker (pounder). Pours out a hazy bannana yellow with an obviously intact trub. Head is slight and mildly creamy. Scent is very estery with a strong wheat backbone and a hint of a citrus element. Taste is very full bodied and surprisingly tart and sweet. definite wheat elements as well as hops, and a distinct fruitiness. Palate is sweet and fruity with a mild yeasty residue intermixed. Very complex flavour but not all of the elements marry perfectly... Still yet a good drink, and very drinkable as well.

B ottle. Pours a very hazy pale gold, with a very tiny tiny wisp of a head. Faint aroma of yeast esters, wheat malt, lemon. Mouthfeel has some faint creaminess, but has more watery texture. Flavor of wheat malt, some phenols, citrus. Some acidity in the finish along with some tang. This is not as bad as the ratings indicate. A crisp refreshing brew, but not a memorable one. Maybe Goose  brewed this one to cater to the Blue Moon drinkers?

Bottle:  Pours a dull orange color with virtually no head.  Has an earthy aroma with some hops and slight citrus.  The taste is very uninspiring... it’s almost like a cross breed between a major macro and an average hefeweizen.  It finishes on an almost sour note.  For a beer, it’s ok.... comparatively to other wheat beers, it’s not good.
not bad, kind of bland.  Basically what the discription says, it doesn’t surprise me in anyway or overwhelm me with something unique, but it is drinkable.

Available all over Chicago, the first couple  I had went down at treat in a night club, come pool hall, in down town. We had been tipped that this place was the ticket and with every girl a 10-bid, the Aussie accent and straight-to-it charm was on form. The beer never tasted as good anywhere else but I can live with that.

12oz bottle labeled BB 091306. Poured a light to medium and slightly hazy golden color with an averaged sized white head. Aromas of wheat, bananas, and some citrus (all on the very light side). Tastes of the same (also very light and watery). Body on the thin and watery side.
Very dissapointing from such a good brewer.  It does look unfiltered.  But unfiltered what grass and lemon?  I brought this home all the way from chicago?
Bottle.  Light sweet apple, banana and wheat aroma.  Hazy orange-yellow color with small head.  Lemon wheat flavor.  Nothing special - an average Am wheat.

Bottle.  Poured a golden that was barely hazy with a thin white head, very pale.  A mild citric fruit aroma with some sweetness.  A pretty tart flavor but lacking the richness of a usual wheat.  Had a clean, crisp finish.  A bit bland.

Yellow hazy pour with a fluffy white head and some wheat floaties that actually add a little character to this beer.  Aromas of lemon yeast and well its kinda like cat piss.  Very watery in the mouth, citrusy and yeasty with a little bit of hops in the finish.  Leaves an almost metallic taste.  The good thing is they are selling a hell of a lot of these which will hopefully get them more money for better projects.

Bottle.<!-- br --> Pours a light yellow with a large head that quickly disapates leaving decent lacing.  Nose is light, bready with a very thin fruity component.  Flavor is watered down, somewhat skunky, apple juice.  It’s not undrinkable, just not something to be seeking out.
pretty unimpressive wheat.  I had two,  but it had an average body with only a touch of wheat and poorly balanced hops.  Drinkable

On tap at Gino’s East Chicago. Pours a nice golden hazy color with a medium white head. Aroma of grass and citrus. Taste of wheat and malt. Smooth as silk and finishes with little tease from the hops.

Bottled. The body had the color of an unfiltered apple cider.  Medium-lasting off-white head.   Mild aroma of tangy wheat with a little yeast.  Flavor was similiar. Overall, just slightly better than your average ho-hum American wheat.
Cloudy golden color with a small but sustained white head.  Wheat and some citrus notes in the aroma.  Creamy wheat mouthfeel and flavor.  Not great but does the job on a warm day.
Cloudy, glowing electric yellow with a slight white head. Light citrusy lemon wheat flavor and nose. Unspectacular.
Shared with Immy.  From bottle.  Pours a cloudy yellow with white head.  Nose is musty wheat and light lemon.  Flavor follows with a rough, metallic aftertaste.  Lightly carbonated palate.

Light yellow and hazy, white crown.  Light to moderate carbonation.  Aroma is of delicate citrus with a little yeasiness.  Wheat malt flavor with hints of lemon.  Not too much hop flavor.  This is a very light and refreshing American Wheat , but not as good as I remember it when it first came out.  Actually, I think I’m going to get another bottle because I think something might be wrong with this one (unless they changed their recipe).  Regardless, Goose Island is still one of my favorite micros.  12 oz bottle, $1.70 at The Party Source.
