Bottle.  Not that great.  Unimpressive, miller lightish appearance and pour, maybe a tad more golden.  Not by any means unappealing, just nothing unique or special.  Barely a wheat beer, saved by a hay / straw flavor with a moderate to strong citrus presence.  My wife loves it.

Not really fair, I don’t like wheat beers, and this has a lot of wheat funk to the flavor. The fruityness makes the wheat flavor more distasteful to me. It is a smooth and fuller bodied beer for the type.
(bottle from kevin i think)murky yellow with a nice foamy white head.aroma and flavor mixed up some hay,wheat,earth,and malts.
About what you would expect from a summer beer.  Light and sweet with a yellow appearance.  More my wife’s preference than my own.
Pours a clear pale yellow with a few floaties and very small white head. Light aroma, wheat and grassy, some floral. Nice sweet flavor. Nice summer beer.
I grew up with the 312 area code in front of my phone number, but fond memories don’t allow me to give this one a great rating (cool bottle though)).  Basic, weak, an OK wheat beer.
Decent unfiltered wheat beer with somewhat weak hints of fruit and clove. Good Summertime beer.
Typically, I’ll turn away from things labled "wheat." But this is light golden in color, a light but thick enough head, and a mild nose, with a hint of fruits. Easy drinking and flavorful.

On tap 7/14 @ the Wrigleyville Brewpub: Pours a cloudy yellow with a white foamy head. Aroma is yeasty with hints of lemon, banana, and spices. Flavor is initially sweet with a grainy finish. A nice summer brew!

Bottle from Secret Santa.  Pours hazy gold/dark straw with 2-finger off-white head.  Aroma of bready malt, some hopcitrus, and some spicy florals.  Medium palate density, with flavors of pale bready malts, heavy hopcitrus and some fruit, and floral spiciness with black pepper.

Bottle (12oz)  Pale hazy yellow with an average white foamy head.  Watery, grainy aroma, hint of fruit, plenty of wheat alright, sort of sweet.  Tastes grainy and a bit papery - incredibly weak, flat, not a very good beer, I’m sorry to say
Light, cloudy color with a white head.  Smell of wheat.  Tastes sweet and wheaty.  A very earthy after taste.
Wheat beer is Gross. So, yeah, it was the only beverage and I was thirsty. thats it. better than BMC still.
an o.k. american wheat but kind of bland.  flavors and aromas consisted mainly of banana, nutmeg, lemon, honey, and hops.  pretty weak for a goose island.
A decent hot-weather American wheat, pours cloudy pale gold, very subtle spicing and watery flavor but thirst-quenching, I consider this an affordable but decent lawnmower beer.

Bottle courtesy of Philip, thanks a lot! Pours hazy yellow with a frothy, white, one finger cap. Good retention. Banana and spices in the nose with some citrus and pineapple. Taste is a watered down version of all elements found in the nose. Its got the banana, lemon, spices, and yeast, but not as full as I would like. Crisp, refreshing, good for the summer, and I like beer in the summer! Thanks Phil!

On tap at the Riverside Tavern in Chicago.  Pours nice and hazy with a hugely retentive head.  The aroma is primarily of wheat and lemongrass.  Flavor and mouthfeel are both soft, with the carryover from the nose of lemongrass and wheat notes.  The finish is somewhat bitter and crisp at the end.  A good summer brew, and definitely a quencher, but what it lacks in complexity makes it "middle of the road" in comparison to others of the style.

After a long day of sighting seeing, this was the first beer that I had and it was new to me.  Very good tasting as it was quite cold.  I had the draught and i’m assuming it tastes the same as the bottled
Hazy pale gold.  Very fizzy.  Wheaty aroma.  Not a lot of character in the taste.  Slightly sour aftertaste.  It is a decent beer - especially when you need a thirst quencher.
Pours a dirty, light straw color with a small, scuzzy head.  Aromas are bready with some pear notes underneath.  Flavor is about the same.  Pretty mild and boring.

Tap in Chicago at Bennigans.  Actually, it looked pretty good for a hefe.  Murky orange pour with a buttload of sediment.  Aroma is... bleh.  Taste is...bleh.  I noted a heavy wheat presence,  thin and watery body and a bit of soapiness.  I like my summer beers, especially on this day in Chitown, but I think the Widmer they had on tap would be a bit better.
Got this as part of a variety pack. Not a bad beer, but nothing special to it.
Kind of weak, not so flavorful, not much better than ordinary. It’s refreshing, but it’s not nearly as good as other Goose Island beers (like Hex Nut Brown Ale). I’m not even sure why they brew this.

Just had to weigh in on this one....

It’s not a bad beer, it has a muted banana/citrus/baking spice thing going on that, coupled with a very light body and low alcohol, really does make for a very refreshing hot-weather beer. The hops come through well as it gets just a little warmer than fridge-cold. It should cut the humidity here in Chicago nicely this summer -- that is, when I’m not drinking Bells Oberon, which is a much better example of the same style.

I am disappointed with the description; what will people think Chicago is like if the brewer calls this beer "densely populated" with flavor, etc., and references the city’s downtown area code? This beer really should be called 847 (the north suburb area code, more exciting than the south or west burbs but it sure isn’t the city).

Got this as part of a Goose Island sampler 12-pack, it’s not a beer I was looking for.

Pale straw color.  I poured too hard and got lots of floaties in suspension.  They eventually settled out.  Attractive white head and a nose of citrus and grass.  I really enjoyed this beer.  It seems to be an American wheat with some flavor.  Bready malts with some lemon citrus flavors.  The finish has some grass and citrus rind in it.  Nice refreshing summer beer.
Very pale straw yellow color with big creamy pure white head. Aroma is slightly citrusy, bit of honey and pear.  Flavor is crisp, clean, almost lager-like, touch of honey. Finish is mildly sweet.

Pours a barely murky, pale yellow, with a small amount of fairly coarse, floating sediment.  Aroma predominantly lemon and yeast, with some light bread and grass.  Flavor not particularly impressive; very light bread and a barely bitter finish; horribly light.  Medium-light body.  Drinkable, but not one of Goose Island’s better offerings.

Bought this as a goose island sampler. bottle. pours a hazy, cloudy yellowish color with a thin short lived head. Aroma is of hops. This beer is different, tastes of spices, hops, and fruity flavor. Overall a descent beer.

Bottle. Pours cloudy neon yellow with thin white head. The aroma is grainy with some zest and hay. The flavor is rather bland, almost like yeasty water. There are som zesty notes in there and some distant hops in the finish. Not very exciting.

Faded whitish lemon yellow with a waffer thin cap of white foam slipping right off to a skinny collar. Some broken up, uneven sheets of lace stick across the glass closer to the liquid.

Aroma is of pale wheat dough, lightly fruit sided with a starchy banana-like cookie mixed with lemon bread poking through.

Taste is fine, wheaty, slippery, a little light in a couple areas, but never weak really. It ghostly stays to the back of the palate with a wheat stamp of lightly snappy texture and buzz while a soft, very light banana/lemon bread dough kinda floats in and out around the corners giving it just enough extra interest helping it from being completely boring or average.

Feel is smooth and malty with a pale wheat backed texture that fits well with what it’s offering. The carbonation is medium and well rounded with a bold snappy front and middle. Finish is a little drab and empty but tends to soften out and build with a light drying wheaty, grassy, doughy malt coating the palate late.

A decent pale wheat brew that can be enjoyed by many a glass full.

bottle. Cloudy lemon color pour with a white head. Aroma is papery and wheaty with not much else going on. More paper and wheat in the flavor with a modicum of citrusy fruit notes. Light, thin, and boring , though not offensive in any way. Goose Island certainly makes more appealing offerings.
cloudy yellow with a white head. clean yeasty nose. watered thin taste. light citrus note. light fruit throughout. a nice thirst quencher.

Pours light hazy yellow with a moderately sized white head.  Aroma is fairly non-descript with some light wheat character.  Medium bodied with medium carbonation.  Starts off with smooth wheat character - not much else at the beginning.  The finish is prickly and somewhat metallic.  This is an okay beer, but not really up to Goose Island standard in my opinion.  Pretty much a plain wheat beer.
Light fruity aroma with some hops is noticible.  The color is a very pale yellow with a small white head.  Slight citrusy and hoppish taste accompanied by a light finish.

I found this to be a good tasting beer, despite the low rating. Light, but flavorful, but, by no means overpowering. Perfect for a boatside session on the dock. a thick white head that fades slowly. Color is dissapointing. Pale yellow, not very cloudy as the description suggests. Aroma is wheat, but smells very much like a lager, and also slight citrus. Flavor is also kind of pale to me. Wheat, citrus, faint fruits. Like I said before, it is light, but very quenching. The boys at GI did a good job on this one.

Had at the brewpub.  Yellow color with a lot of carbonation.  Thick foamy head.  No real discernable taste.  It was very smooth, but it might as well ahve been water.  
Earlier Rating: 4/11/2006 Total Score: 2.7
When I was at Goose Island, this was called Urban Wheat.  Yellow.  Highly carbonated with a thick foamy head.  No taste.  Very smooth.  Might as well drink water.

Pale gold color clouded by hefe trub.  Not much head for a wheat.  Fairly pleasant sour aroma.  Yeasty flavor with just a hint of grapefruit.  Not sweet, not sour, not very flavorful.  Inoffensive but nothing to write home about.  312 is the Chicago area code, but if you’re looking for a great wheat beer this is a wrong number.

Had side by side with thier hefeweizen.  Very similar to eachother, except the urban wheat was very very pale gold and the hefe was a bit deeper- both were cloudy.  Aroma is light bready wheat, a crisp light citrus character and a touch of herbal/citrus/orange hops.  Flavor is lightly fruity, bready, and lightly bitter.  Finishes crisp and clean yet pretty smooth overall.

Poured a nice hazy gold colr with a tight golden head and some fizzy bubbles in it’s own weizen style glass.  A small yeasty nose.  Fairly bland wheat flavor, but really decent mouthfeel.  Not bad, but not great.  Worth trying if your in the mood for a wheat.

The bottle poured a hazy pale yellow beverage with a small smooth white head that lasted well and left decent lacing on the glass. The aroma presented a spicy blend of hop aroma with citrus and earthy tones lurking in the background. The body was medium-light with lively carbonation and a somewhat dry texture. The flavor started off tart and watery. It had a medium finish with a tart, somewhat dry character leaving a clean mouthfeel.

This one sort of disappointed me after enjoying the 5 new Wheat series from Goose Island.  312 was way, way too light and lifeless.  If I tried very hard, I could deciphor a hint of the wheat beer flavor and spice, but it just fell short in terms of body and flavor.  The Bud Lite of Wheat beers.
More hopped than most other wheat ales ive had. Cloudy yellow pour, light head. Decent

this is better than a 2.8 i feel.  i mean, it’s no gumballhead, but it’s not supposed to be.  a good summer session beer by most measures, i think an otherwise muted citrus character is pronounced well by a slice of lemon/orange.  certainly best out of the weizen glass.

When poured the beer looks to be unfiltered.  Hazy straw like color with lots of floating sediment.  Citrusy lemon nose.  Mildly carbonated and dry, with notes of lemon and grass flavors, and a touch of hops in the finish.  An okay beer/wheat.
Pours a golden yellow/amber.  Aromas of lemon, grains, celery.  Flavor is crisp, dry, sweet malt, and a mild hop.

12 oz bottle. Pours pale yellow, active carbonation with a quickly fading white head.  Smells sweet and earthy alike.  Very bubbly mouthfeel with a citrus crispness that’s fairly enjoyable.  Very mouth-drying finish.  I think more malt would give this basically decent beer a reason to rave.
Pours pale and hazy with a frothy head. The aroma is mild with a citric character. Boring and unsubstantial. Thin body.

This hoppy metro wheat is spicy but smooth and leaves the consumer with hints of crisp lemon and banana tastes and smell. Goose island has been consistent with this beer like their others with big bold hoppy tastes but mixing it with a easy to drink highly hopped tasty wheat.

Slightly cloudy yellow body with a thick white head.  Aroma has some hops, citrus and a grassy smell.  Flavor is mostly absent, but hints at some citrus and wheat.  Palate is watery.  When Goose Island has the chops to make beers as good as the Bourbon County Stout or the Imperial IPA, I don’t know why they waste their time on this one.  Not a very impressive beer.

bottle - This is an okay wheat beer.  Like most American wheats, it’s a bit sweet and easy to drink.  There’s a hint of citrus in the flavor and very little noticeable hops.  It’s just  rather unremarkable and thin.

12oz. Bottle:  I thought it looked quite thin and not appatizing, until I looked a little closer.  There was a steady carbonation moving throughout and a strange suspended lacing that was beautiful in a beer kind of way.  The head explodes foamy only to dissapate immidieatly following an agressive pour.  The aroma is grassy, citrus, urine, doughy, pine.  The flavor is well ... less than the 6 I gave the aroma.  Very dissapointing.  Its a Goose Island, it shouldn’t be bad, but there is almost nothing there.  The palate is stiff, stale and biting.  Not a beer I will try twice unfortuantly.
This isn’t too bad of a wheat beer.  Not very citrusy, but it still has some fruity flavors.  Very full bodied.
A skunky smelling beer that looks like piss yellow. Not very flavorful and a low palate. Overall I’d say if you want a good wheat ale take Blue moon over this crap.
Pour is hazy golden yellow with a nice tight bubbled off white head...smell is faintly hoppy with some yeast and light lemon zest...taste is clean and sweet...good American Wheat...
Had this from the tap. Delicously fruity, sweet, with hints of citrus. Slightly bitter and easy drinking.
Draught at College Street Billiards in Iowa City. Cloudy yellow color with thin white head that laced the glass.  Pleasany yeasty citrus aroma and flavor with nice caramel undertones. Very good beer.

A pretty unpleasant attempt at American Wheat. LIghtly clouded yellow color, fair head. Aroma lemony, very slightly floral. Flavor also lemony, a rising of too much hops in the finish. Some vaguely minty wheat malt, but mainly a weird bitter cooked zucchini-asparagus bread-dough  character.

Available on tap from Goose Island (Wrigleyville), Chicago, IL.  Hazy golden yellow hued wheat ale with no discernable head.  No discernable aroma or carbonation.  Light bodied ale that starts with lightly sweet malt with citrus flavor and slight oxidation off-flavor of cooked vegetable (mushroom?). Short bland finish.  No discernable hop contribution. A rather mediocre beer.  Sampled during lunch at Goose Island. UPDATE:  (02.18.06)  Sampled at FebFest ’06, Libertyville, IL.  Poured from a 12 oz brown bottle.  Pours hazy straw-colored with small white head.  Smoky, spicy nose. Light-to-medium bodied that starts with light malt sweetness and smoky, honey flavors. Finishes with light malt fade.  A decent, drinkable wheat beer, but not one of Goose Island’s better beers. Rating remains the same.

Bottle. Pours cloudy amber with a large frothy white head that was mostly lasting. Light citrus wheat aroma. Light to medium body and a thin texture.  Moderate sweet  wheat flavor with small bitter finish of short duration.

I have been a fan of Goose Island Beers for over 2 years so naturally I bought this without question, needless to say I was shocked. Disappointing, This beer lacks flavor. The Color of this beer is a Deep Yellow color (Cloudy from being unfiltered), The Aroma is pretty tame, nothing harsh, no real characteristics, the one quality the beer has is that it leaves no aftertaste, but the negative side to that is that it also leaves no taste while drinking it. I drank 3 bottles trying it at different temperatures from at the point just before freezing, at roughly 45°, and also at about 60° None of which changed the flavor only changed the film it left when drinking.This brewig company is still one of my favorites, just not this beer.

(12 oz bottle: Obtained in trade with OhioDad, thanks Scott!) Best when consumed by 20-Feb-06.  One of my least favorite beer styles, and this American Wheat from Goose Island lives up to my expectation of mediocre beer.  Minimally sweet, only lightly hoppy or bitter, and with a non-descript wheat maltiness, this beer mostly just tastes like cardboard, which I find a little surprising.  A very slight fruitiness hides far in the background.  The nose is papery and dry.  Light bodied, but not watery, and carbonation is fine.  Medium straw, somewhat hazy, and capped initially by a good inch of white, rocky head before it settles to a filmy layer.  A few small patches of lace remain behind on the glass.  Not only is this a boring, lightly flavored beer, but you know you’re in trouble when cardboard is seemingly the most prominent of the flavors.
A pleasant wheat to drink. Not overbearing with the sour mash taste that the stronger wheats get into. At least a two bottle buy.

Surprisingly, a pretty yeasty, wheaty brew from Goose Island.  Almost a german hefe, though not quite.  Cloudy and murky with a good amount of flavor.  Easy to drink, yet overly fizzy as wheats tend to be. 
Earlier Rating: 1/16/2004 Total Score: 1.9
A fairly typical American Wheat - not that yeasty or funky.  Light yellow in color.  Some aroma (faint).  Acceptable.
Pleasant but not particularly impressive. Very easy to drink but rather bland, flavorless.
Ok, so initially this taste like sour water on the first sitp.  After a couple drinks, it taste better, but still not all that good.
medium yellow, slightly hazy with lots of bubbles.  Thick foamy head that disipates quickly.  Slight lemon and orange aroma.  wheat/lemon flavor.  Yum!

This was definitely the best beer that I had during my time in Chicago.  It has a very yeasty aroma and a cloudy appearance.  It is clearly unfiltered and tastes wonderful.  It’s very creamy with the taste of yeast and hops, with a hint of lemon?  This is a  very good beer, which I highly recommend.

Bottle--Drank in a park at an evening party, so the appearance was hard to rate, probably a cloudy yellow color with medium carbonation, lemon aroma and taste.  Perfect drink for a perfect Labor Day picnic.

Hazed, straw yellow look, big, booming head, commands the top of the glass, but assuredly simmers down. 

Aroma: soft, spicy, citric. Banana and lemon on top, creamy underneath...nice. 

Nice in the taste, too. Soft and mellow, fruit and light spices. Delightfully flavorful, and terrifically quenching. Very downable, light and easy, delicate in flavor, but tasty as heck.
Reminds me a bit of Oberon, without the funky yeast. 
If that silly distributor would have let me pick this up in a 6-pack, I surely would have gone through plenty over the summer.

Bottle:  White head, lacing is good.  Cloudy gold in color.  Aroma is wheaty, lemony, hints of banana and clove as well.  Taste is good, a solid offering for a wheat.  I had some bad experiences with wheat beers when I first tried, but I think they are starting to grow on me.  Maybe I just had bad imitations of them before I started rating them.  For this style, this is excellent.  Can’t totally understand why this is getting such low ratings.

On tap at the Crescent Moon Alehouse. Great tap handle of a black telephone receiver. Paqle yellow with a fleeting white head. Somewhat hazy and cloudy, but not opaque. Citrus orange aroma. Body is light. Quick crisp finish. Solid beer.

Thanks again to my secret santa for another  new beer.  He did only send me 24 of them. Rather attractive hazy yellow color with a thin head.  Aroma is like fresh hay, yeast and lemon.  Flavor is pretty enjoyable, and very drinkable.  This has a nice light wheat and lemon taste and a somewhat sticky malt backing.  The palate is pretty boring though.  Seems like lemonade until the very end where the malt actually shows up for the party.

"Urban Wheat" is apparently some sort of beer code for "crappy vaguely craft-esque brew designed to appeal to a random BMC drinker who’s feeling adventurous".  Light gold, not promising.  Nose of soap, vague wheat, and vegetables, overcooked beans or something.  Thin, barely wheaty, hardly any esters or clove, but does manage to be somewhat harsh and bitter at the end.  Oh, and it’s thin and crappy.
On tap. Pale yellow color. Watery mouthfeel. Weak grainy taste. Fizzy carbonation. Weak smell. A little better than your average macro is the best I can say here.
Very carbonated, very filling.  I had two large drafts with dinner in Wadsworth last nite, couldn’t finish the last one due to feeling very full.
(draft) Take a light American wheat and spray lemon pledge in it. Not the worst thing I’ve ever tasted, but far from the best.
Cloudy golden color, dry and flat tasting, watery. Finish is thin and dry. I expected more.

A solid wheat ale. It has a lemony flavor to it on its own (I don’t like to squeeze fruit juices in my wheat ales as a rule), nice head and lacing. It pours hazy golden. The aroma is mostly of lemon - I couldn’t smell anything like wheat, though. Nice carbonation and refreashing, cleansing, dry aftertaste. Not watery at all, rather it has a good medium-bodied mouthfeel.

Poured into a 1/2 liter wheat glass expecting little head formation.  Pours yellow with intense carbonation and a thick white head that diminishes quickly.  Only slightly cloudly, mostly clear.  Aroma of citrus and Cascade hops with hints of coriander and clove.   Cereal grainy taste. Cardboard malt and wheat finish.  Typical American wheat beer.  No yeast flavor at all. Mouthfeel is watery and only lightly carbonated.  Smells MUCH better than it tastes.  Hops save what could be a bad beer, making this drinkable, but not good.  A dissapointment from Goose Island.
(Tap)  Pours a clear yellow body with a small white head.  Aroma of lemon and wheat.  Flavor of malt and a little bit of hops and not much else.  Creamy, smooth, soft mouthfeel.

I usually like a lot of Goose Island’s products, such as their Hex Nut and their IPA. Not this though. terrible. Tastes like water. I literally think there are el cheapo domestics that are better than this.

Lightly hazed straw color with a moderate foamy white head. HInts of wheat and malt which yield to the signature pine and citrus cascade hops. Smells much more like a light APA than a wheat of any nature. Lightly grainy and full light citrus flavors. Light and spritzy in feel. Sweet finish that contributes to a lack of quenching ability. Actually a more interesting american wheat.

Poured out a hazy BMC looking pour with tiny ring of white fizzy bubbles as its head.  Nose is bigger on hops than a BMC for sure, actually its quite hoppy in general.  Flavor is full of hop and wheat.  Plus some slight fruit n dough.  A bit on the watery side, but on a nice hot summer day what more could you want in a beer?
on tap at GI - Clybourn.  a hazy light yellow with a citrus aroma.  crisp tasting with light lemon, citrus peel flavor.  my swill drinking friends liked it, but GI does others MUCH better.

Bottle.  Poured a fairly clear yellow.  Quickly dissapating head, no lacing.  Aromas of faint fruit, peach-like.  Sweet maltyness with a crisp hoppy bite.  Didn’t remind me of any wheat I’ve ever had. More like a kolsch, or sommat. Not bad though, a real quencher.

Pours a mildly cloudy piss yellow with a fizzy white head. Aroma of husks and c-hops. Flavor is mildly sweet med. sour with a very mild citrus twang. Med. light body. No real bitternesss. I hate American Wheats. Can I get an Amen from the congregation!

Mild aromas of peach, apple, and honeysuckle.  Some wheat.  Clear pale yellow, no head.  Apricot.  Hops up front, very fresh, clean, somewhat grassy bitterness.  Carbonation on the high side.  Fizzy mouthfeel.  Wheat in middle, dough-whole grain cereal finish.  Light bitter aftertaste.  Refreshing.

On tap at wrigleyville...Poured a golden blonde with large white head continuously fed by abundant carbonation. Aromas were grainy and slightly hoppy with some citrus mixed in. I found the flavor to be somewhat boring, watery and unfulfulling. G.I. has done much better.
(draught) Pale slightly hazy yellow with abundant white head. Lots of bubbles. Hints of lemon and banana. Cold and crisp - good choice for a hot Chicago summer afternoon.

Hazy golden pour.   Light aroma with hints of tangerine.  A bit fizzy on the palate, with flavors of melon, orange, and yeast.  A bit light on character, but aren’t most non-Gumballhead American wheats?  Certainly drinkable.
Personally I do not care for any U.S. brewer that claims any Hefe style beer and does not deliver in the aroma or taste.  This does not deliver on any category  For the price why not buy a BMC.
Bottle. Pours a light orange color with very thin fizzy head. Nose is lemons and wheat. Taste is watery with some light orange flavors to it, a small amount of acidic citrus. Good on a hot day

There really wasn’t a lot to this beer...  Cloudy yellow pour with a small white head.  Only some slight citrusy aroma, but you have to sniff really hard.  Flavor was wheaty, with a little of the citrus hoppiness from the nose.  Light-bodied and watery.  Not a whole lot in the finish, either.

Pours a cloudy light yellow, white a white reasonably sustaining head.  Aromas are of lemon and other citrus with a mellowness from the wheat.  Flavor is slightly watered down, with the wheat and lemons up front.  No lasting finish, mouthfeel is light and watery.  A nice session beer during the summer.

So what makes this Urban, I dont know? Pours a cloudy yellow with a slight layers of white head. Aroma is lemon bread, pleasant. Tastes like it smells, wheat, yeast, and lemon are noted. Light body and slick. Not bad when you are in the mood for something on the mellow side of the scale.

Bottle.  The aroma was sweet lemon candy with wheaty malt undertones.  Really, my first impression was that this smelled kind of like a Pinot Grigio.  Fruity like that.  The appearance was a hazy straw yellow with hardly any head.  The taste was primarily dominated by a light wheat taste, almost exclusively.  I thought to my self that this needed some type of fruit wedge floating in it.  The body was creamy and light.  Not too bad, but there was not much character in the taste (which is why I think a piece of fruit would do this justice).

Pour is a cloudy yellow with a white head.  Aroma is nice and zesty lemon with a touch of hop.  Flavor is rather bland though with a touch of lemon and cream.  Can’t really recommed it but can’t hate it either.  East to drink on a hot humid night.

312, dammit, this used to be my area code before chicago went and stole it, then they stole whatever they replaced it with and left 630.  As for the beer, it is yellow, has the aroma of hay and citrus zest, boring body to it, blah, and dont let it get warm.

Bottle.  Pours a hazy yellow.  Smells of orange and another fruit I can’t seem to peg.  Taste is is citrusy with notes of wheat, yeast and hops hiding quietly in the glass.  Pretty smooth and easily drinkable.  This would make a great session beer.

Light in color
Light in head and lacing
Light in tatste
Light in just being a beer
Nothing here to really talk about

First of all, I like Goose product...they brew many fine beers...they know what they’re doing...but this is a trainwreck of a wheat.  It looks like neon urine, smells like corn, and tastes like nothing at all.  I am offended by this beer.   (On the other hand, maybe I had a bad bottle?)

I really like this beer. Probably my new favorite wheet beer.  This is because it’s really mild and doesn’t have an overwhelming citrus flavor that most wheet beers do.  It’s really crisp and easy to get down, and there’s still that slight fruity flavor.
Good session beer in the summertime. Nice white head, good lacing, yellow color. Fruity flavor. Not overpowering, but good to drink.

Thanks to Darkover for the trade. Apparently wheat doesn’t grow too well in urban areas. Hazy yellow-gold color with a thin white head and scant lacing. The aroma is faintly wheaty with a touch of malt. Light-bodied with a slick mouthfeel. Tastes like a cross between a Wheat and an Adjunct Lager. Mild wheat, hops and corn are the prevalent flavors. The finish is crisp and lightly hoppy and fruity. Not bad really, it just doesn’t need to be this bland.
Hazy yellow with a white head.  Aroma of citrus and wheat. Very watery with some lemon flavor. Sour finish.
Looks nice, tastes bad.  Way, way to carbonated.  Made my eyes water to take a drink.  A metallic, watery taste to go along with the fizziness.  This one was very disappointing.

Cloudy, hazy yellow color, with a huge white frothy and sticky head that stays around for awhile. This has citrus and wheat aromas, light wheaty, and some lemon flavor, medium in body, nice soft and creamy mouthfeel, has a nice clean and refreshing finish, a bit on the bland side.

Aroma: at first it was citrusy and wheaty, but later became rancid (not skunky, but some other sour smell).  Appearance: cloudy straw, with a large head that lasts a couple minutes.  The flavor is unexceptional, and is very bland.  Not much hop, malt, wheat, or yeast flavor.  None of the fruity tastes that a good wheat beer gives you.  The palate was likewise thin and watery.  This is a sub-standard wheat beer, and I would recomment Boulevard’s instead if you are looking for a good wheat beer made here in the midwest.
Straw yellow soft gentle pour leads to light carbonation through clear direction. Some citrus flavor. Not bad for an American wheat.  Entertaining but not much benefit.
On tap at Clybourn:  Soft yellow.  Thin, and not remarkable.  Nice citrusy tang.  A little bit of funk? Not as bad as some say.  Weird label.  Thanks to  Ma Beth.

12 oz bottle:  Moderately hazy golden yellow w/ very little thin, white head.  Lightly floral w/ grainy and wheat malt aromas.  Some over cooked canned corn(DMS) and lightly plasticky aromas as well.  There’s also a Catawba grape fruitiness...odd!  Well balanced flavor, wheat malt is predominant.  Actually is sort of tastes like Natural Light with hops!  Light corn flavor, finish is sort of bland w/ a short lived wheat malt flavored aftertaste.  Medium carbonation, smooth m/f, light body.  I’m not too hip on some of the aromas like the plasticky or corn, and the flavor is rather bland, even for a wheat.
Dull, hazy yellow hue with respectable head.  Citrus bloom aroma.  Mellow flavors ... mild yeast, white bread, citrus.  Sweet, lemony.

Good for an American wheat.  Light wheat aroma and light wheat taste.  There is pleasant citrus, and it is a little sweet.  I would prefer a hefe, but this lighter beer with the citrus is an ok substitute.
Just a bad beer.  Weak nose and palate and flavor.  Weak, bland, dull on all fronts.  Very forgettable.
Very disappointed in this GI offering.  Aroma and taste were very bland. Not much to offer here.
Here’s a lemony snicket tart and tangy wheat beer.  Nice looking - hazy pale golden, very good head and lacing.  Aroma has some clove to it’s sweetness.  Very refreshing flavor, easty to drink.

On tap at brewery.  Aroma leaning more towards a mild ale with lemon accents.  Taste is sour, yeasty and lemon-lime.  Sharp and acidic, with some pine elements.  Thin, but smooth.  Too much yeast, carbonation and hops, but where are the malts?  Crisp, clean and sour finish.  Overall, not very good - like a pale lager with extra yeast and lemon juice.
Had this one bottled.  Somewhat cloudy dark yellow color, thick head, nose of hops and bread, clean tastes of grapefruit, very, very good wheat beer.

Not too bad at all. While the American Wheat pales next to the Belgian Wit or German Weisen this is a nice example of the domestic style. The 312 is the Chicago area code. The inhearent problem of this style is that it has too strong of a hop-grapefruit taste. This is a good beer though

On draught at clybourn. Hazy yellow with a thin white head that diminishes fast. Aroma is honey, lemon, and wheat. I was caught off guard by a hop presence to start the beer. Fizzy in the mouth with a sligh lemon taste. Not a big fan of American Wheats, but this is one of the better ones in this style.
weak in flavor. not a pleasant after taste. I think this is the only Goose Island I have never not been happy with.

A bit too acidic for an American wheat, sofaras I’m concerned.  Nice look, with a tall frothy head.  (It’s probably why they serve it in a pils glass at the pub.)  Quite carbonated.  Mainly lemon and banana come across in the flavor.  Clean... pretty much of a "wet" finish.

Goose Island Beer Company - Clybourn, Chicago, IL

5 oz sample at the Clybourn location.  Unfiltered luminous gold, thick frothy head...pleasant lemony/grainy nose...assertive sourish body, fresh and fragrantly herbal (thyme-tarragon), but a little watery and dull in the end.

Pours a golden yellow with a quickly dissipating white head. Smells slightly fruity and hoppy. The flavor is slightly hoppy, similar to Honker’s but softer, and fruitty. Not much in the way of wheat. The palate is creamy and easy to drink. Enjoyable if you’re kickin back a few.

I saw this brew on tap at the Fox & Hound chain restaurant in Schaumburg last night, and decided to check it out.  It had a slightly darker yellow color, and a quickly dissipating white creamy head.  The taste had a short burst of spice, followed by a lot of wheat protein and "graininess".  The finish was a dirty/slightly grassy hops kind of thing.  It would be a thirst quencher on a hot day, but something you might get tired of real fast.

goose island clybourn / hazy golden yellow with little white head. slightly cremey palate, just a bit sweet, and surprisingly hard to keep drinking, but it was nonetheless enjoyable. hell, i drank it and liked it! egh... throw me a gumballhead, rather.
Hazy gold color with no head.  Vague wheat aroma.  Fairly sweet taste with hints of wheat.  Oddly enough, it seemed a bit dusty too.  Eh, not bad.
Light Yellow Coloring.  Sweet Flavor with Wheat and Lemon Coming out... Crisp and Dry Ending.  A Decent Wheat.

For some reason I was expecting a hefe but that clearly wasn’t the case here. It’s very pale yellow in color and slightly hoppy and fruity. Not bad but uneventfull to say the least.

Update: I’m raising my rating of this. It is not exceptional, I suppose, but for what it wants to be, it does very well. Good for drinking out in the sun or just relaxing when you don’t want to drink anything too complicated. No flavor flaws as far as I’m concerned and it’s only true fault is having too much carbonation. I drink it all the time.

Also, it seems like people are degrading this for having no wheat character. I hate to break it to you people but wheat doesn’t taste a whole hell of a lot different than barley in a beer. I could make a pale ale using 100% wheat instead of barley and maybe one out of ten of you would know w/o me telling you. This is basically a light pale ale brewed w/ some wheat.

on draft some deep dish place: asked the bartender what the 312 was...smart ass told me it was the area code...didnt really care about that wanted to know what kind of a beer it was/is....in my opinion a light summer wheat beer.  pours golden clear with fizzy white mushy top.   no real nose just some suttle wheat/yeast dampness. not a great beer in the mouth . very weak and bland...pushed into almost a pils flavor.  slight lemon back in the mix...gritty and not enjoyable to drink. my friend sent it back.......the other goose islands are much better.

I didn’t get the 312-area code connection until I read it here.  My best guess was that this was the supposed, artificially-accurate number of carbs in a glass of this beer: 3.12.  Indeed, I presumed this was a low-carb beer.  Light, yellow, and weak.  Good carbonation, but a grassy flavor and overall hollowness make it a forgettable throwaway beer. (on tap at Clybourn location)
ON TAP - If this was the last Wheat at the bar, I’d switch to something else.  Artificial tasting and left me with a grimy feeling in my mouth.  Really poor, perhaps the worst Wheat I’ve ever tasted.

Draught:  Light yellow in color.  Clear and sparkling.  Small white head.  Good lacing.  Hay and straw malts.  Light, grassy hops.  Light body.  Slick texture.  Fizzy.  Bitter finish.  Wheaty.  I also agree with the comments by Mariano500.

tap-old chicago-rockford, IL-pours cloudy yellow with a decent white head-aroma was yeasty, wheaty, and grainy.  flavors are slighty hoppy and grainy, but quite refreshing i thought.  Not as bad as others say it is.  This would be a good refresher on a hot NM day!

A very, very bland Summer Wheat, which really surprised me when I started to notice how hard they have been promoting this.  They have a new tapper just for this beer in the shape of a telephone (312 is an old Chicago area code).  Light all around, golden yellow and quite bubbly.  Grassy nose.  Malts are sweet but thin. watery. Grainy and dry at the finish.

well, the only reason I actually had this was a tour. I’m not  a fan of wheats in general, and this wasn’t an exception. Hazy banana color, little head. Smelled of corn? some beer smells. Nothing extraordinary. I suppose if you’re a fan of this style, it would be very easy to drink, but I didn’t like the flavortaste...
on tap at GI clyborn.  nice white head that left behind some lace.  clean taste.  some wheat.  a little hops.  good beer, but many better choices from goose island  exist.
Light hazy lemon color.  No nose presence or anything.  Flat, nearly tasteless experience.  Some hops and bitterness, but no yeast, no citric flavors.  Watery texture made it easy to drink.
Pilsnery color, light golden, hazy.  Not much carbonation.  Fuzzy mouthfeel.  Light hoppiness.  Malt apparent.  Fairly unimpressive.

Hazy, pale hay with a small, but retentive white head.  The aroma is nothing spectacular with all elements being rather subdued.  Banana, clove, yeasty esters, citrus fruit and lactic acid all make an appearance without much contribution from any hops.  The light and airy mouthfeel definitely screams of summer beer that goes down without making any impact.  The flavors are also light and bland, just like the aroma.  While I said in my rating of the Willow Street Wheat that I thought it was a close match to Oberon, all signs point to this being the actual market competitor.  It’s just too damn boring to be something I would ever buy again.  I would rather see them scrap this one and bottle the Willow St. Wheat.   Actually, perhaps something to compete with Victory Whirlwind and just forget about Oberon...

Sampled again in the bottle. Poured a light and cloudy yellow. Aroma is sharp with lemons and some floral hops citrus. The taste has light lemons and flowers. Surprisingly hoppy for an American Wheat. Nice grassy taste with a refreshing lemon note in the background. Not nearly as openly sour as some in the style.

Aroma:  slight tropical fruit and grainy aromas


Appearance:  light yellow, small head


Flavor:  tropical fruit flavors, slight hoppy with strong grainy aftertaste followed by mild fruitness like an apple cider


Palate:  very smooth and carbonated--like Sprite or Ginger Ale sodas
Smell of LME and light melon fruitiness.  Bland and slightly bready flavor.  Some light lemon is all I get.  Clear yellow and fizzy.

Chicago Real Ale Fest draft inside the brewery.  The glass I was served in contained a large head of white colored finely sized mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a minimal lace.  The body was straw yellow in color and softly carbonated.  The aroma was floral wheaty and mold in the nose.  The mouth feel was tingly and smooth with a mild wheat finish that was somewhat flat.  It had a mild thin malty wheat flavor.

Crystal yellow huw with small white head. Faint citrus and noble hops aroma with additional buttered biscuit and vegetable esters. The taste hasa a citric twang with a mild malt base. Chalky and lightly bitter upon the finish. Thin-bodied, clean and crisp. Another ho-hum American krystal wheat but without any true yeast characteristics.
Golden color with a small white head.  Lemon, hay, and banana aroma.  Wheaty taste, slightly carbonated and mildy hoppy. Overall a rather plain brew, but not offensive.

Bottled and Draft at the Brewery: The next beer in their specialty retail line (as soon as they get approval for the labels). Baseline example of an American wheat: pale yellow beer under a bubbly head that clings a little to the plastic glass. Not as fizzy as other wheats. Hop taste is more traditionally bitter, not fruity like 3F's Gumballhead, and very well balanced to the malt profile. Sampling from the bottle reveals a slightly fruitier profile.

Bottle, 8/17. Not much that'd make me change my rating. Pours into a .5l Weizen glass, it kicks up a fine, rocky wheat head. Light body, low carbonation, decent taste with little perceptible hop note. Well balanced summer refresher.
